												Do you like comics?Do you like atmosphere?Do you like having two demonic tentacle heads protruding from your back that allow you to whip, grab, dismember, and look bad♥♥♥♥♥Welcome to The Darkness 2.The single player campaign is not too long depending on difficulty level and your level of expertise, but I found the story and atmosphere so refined that I thoroughly enjoyed my play through and recommended it. Also of note is the Vendettas campaign. There is a 4 player online co-op that intertwines with the single player story filling in some back story. Overall Vendettas is a fun diversion with friends but a little repetitive. You don't get to play as the main character Jackie, instead one of a set of four mercenaries that each have a personal weapon infused with Dark Essence.Now for the gameplay. The Darkness II finally disproves the theory that developers have to leave the main protagonist as hollow as possible in first person shooters so that the gamers can fully immerse themselves. This is just lazy storytelling and don't let anyone tell you differently. The Darkness is a game of two parts. Light and dark. Players experience the tender heart of Jackie when he is around Jenny and Aunt Sarah. But then players go out and start shooting guys and flinging fan blades at them with one demon arm while decapitating them with the other demon arm. In The Darkness II you quad-wield and your survival depends on it. At first it can seem a bit much to keep track of, grabbing things and throwing things and slashing and shooting all at once. But once you learn to multitask you will feel like a God. It's intoxicating. The Darkness becomes an extension of your will and soon you are slaying rooms full of enemies with gleeful abandon. There is an upgrade system to tailor the combat to your preferences and the point system that pays for your new abilities will encourage you to perform gruesome executions. The game is bloody. But due to a smart move on the developer's behalf, the cell-shaded comic style graphics make all the gore less disgusting. This time around the enemies have their own supernatural weapons at their disposal, a noted improvement over the last game.Inside all of us there's a violent beast that needs to be sated, lets it bleed over into our real lives. This game does just that. Incredibly violent, and intensely satisfying. My only wish is that it were longer. Great fun; A must have.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												n a strange coincidence I started playing The Darkness II at about roughly the same time I started Alan Wake. The plots in each game revolve heavily on light and darkness, which is really just a play on the classic good vs. evil conflict. In Alan Wake the protagonist uses light as a weapon to destroy and evade evil, but in The Darkness II the protagonist depends on the darkness to literally envelop himself in evil to defeat enemies, becoming the monstrous “host” of the Darkness.Jackie Estacado, Don of the Franchetti family, has laid low with the Darkness bottled up for two years following the death of his girlfriend Jenny. After a failed attempt on his life, Jackie is ready to unleash the Darkness once again, to exact revenge and to continue fighting for Jenny. His new enemies have been tracking him for years, and their leader, Victor Valente, is after the Darkness for himself. Jackie also faces a reality problem, not knowing if what he is experiencing is real while having several brief visions of a psychiatric ward throughout the game.Before I continue I’d first like to include a precautionary note. The Darkness II is definitely what I’d refer to as an adult oriented game. The entire thing revolves around harnessing evil for violence, has many demonic themes (eating hearts of dead enemies to regain health, collecting dark relics for points, etc.), includes adult themes, and is not something I’d ever buy for a kid. With the appropriate rating there’s nothing wrong that. I’m not discounting the game for this at all, but the “dark” themes turned me off a bit, and I’d guess that reactions to these themes among FPS fans would be mixed.With that note out of the way, I’d like to continue with an annoyance. Game assistants, such as Wheatly in Portal 2, seem to be popping up more and more these days. The inclusion of the Darkling in The Darkness II was fine functionally, but it seemed like the character was intended to appeal to a younger audience, which didn’t make much sense to me. For example, there were several times where the Darkling would run up to an enemy’s body I had just killed to pass gas or urinate on it. If you’re making an adult game, I just don’t quite understand why you would include something like this. The Darkling just seemed too offensive to me; I wasn’t able to appreciate the character at all. I also feel like the horror element to the game would have been enhanced if the player were forced to play alone.On the positive side I’d say that despite playing on rails, The Darkness II is a fairly solid and intense first-person shooter. I didn’t encounter any bugs or gameplay issues, and there were plenty of enemies to kill. Locales were mixed, and even though I found it a bit cliché, the vacant carnival level was definitely an enjoyable setting. There weren’t exactly a large variety of weapons, but the inclusion of the ability tree, in which new abilities can be purchased with dark essence points, helped. The abilities tree seemed like kind of an afterthought on the whole, but it’s better than just having generic weapons. Items such as extended gun clips, a swarm distraction to stun enemies, and better weapon handling can be purchased in the abilities tree. The Darkness itself is really the most powerful weapon, which can destroy enemies in a couple of swipes if they’re close enough. When things got crazy and I was surrounded by enemies the Darkness always seemed to allow me to break out; it was pretty incredible to use.Another strong point of The Darkness II was the voice acting. It wasn’t all great, but I was especially impressed with David Hoffman’s portrayal of the half deranged occultist Johnny Powell (example trailer linked) and Brian Bloom as the new voice of Jackie. The loading segments in which each of these characters reveal more of the storyline were some of the most memorable portions of the game. Voice acting in video games can vary quite a bit, and it’s not usually very good; this game is definitely an exception. Sound effects and music were also decent.Visuals were also a positive, but you shouldn’t go into it expecting total realism. The Darkness II was developed using cel-shaded animation, which is different from the first game. The cel-shading was different than what I have seen before in that it was subtle and at times almost unnoticeable. There was definitely a nice balance between realism and animation, which really made it seem as if I was experiencing the graphic novel on which the game is based.In terms of difficulty, I’d have to say that I didn’t find The Darkness II overly challenging. The AI was easy to avoid and fool for the most part, but there were a few portions that I had to replay several times to finally move forward. Being equipped with the Darkness felt as if I was much more powerful than the majority of the enemies.In addition to the single-player campaign The Darkness II also includes a Vendetta mode in which you can carry out missions for Jackie as one of four characters with special powers. These missions can be played alone or in co-op mode, but the Vendettas are definitely not the main attraction. It’s one of those extra things thrown in that you try once or twice but to which you never come back.Overall, I’d say that The Darkness II is a decent shooter, but there is nothing in it that is amazing; it’s respectable but mostly predictable. Playing a more or less “evil” character felt different compared to all the other standard “save the Earth” games, but other than the Darkness it doesn’t include much that hasn’t been done before. The story and voice acting is a big plus. The main campaign isn’t that long, and the AI isn’t the greatest, but it is intense and still enjoyable if you’re an FPS fan.

AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)Game Name: The Darkness II Original Release: 2012 Genre Tags: FPS; Dark; Action; Psychological; Story Rich My Overall Grade: A- Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 6-18 hours Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseursREVIEWThe Darkness II is an action FPS with strong narrative elements and a stylish, graphic-noir atmosphere.  The gameplay feels both familiar and fresh simultaneously, while the characters and story keep the player engaged and interested.  Also, the addition of an XP system and skill-trees allow the player to continue to work towards new goals and to customize their character according to their preferred combat style.  All of these elements mesh together to create a very enjoyable game that I feel all but the most extremely discerning gamers should appreciate.One of the most intriguing aspects of The Darkness II is the story, and the characters that make it.  The twisted and confused thoughts of the main character set the tone of the game from the first level, and evolve as the story progresses, in a similar fashion to games like Max Payne and Alan Wake.  The auxiliary characters are diverse and interesting, enticing the player to initiate optional conversations. The narrative is a perfect blend of mafia drama and psychological thriller that should enthrall anyone who enjoys being told a good story.The actual gameplay experience is also exquisite.  The combination of familiar FPS aspects with some well-integrated novelty goes a long way to make the game downright fun.  There are various guns and abilities to use to wreak havoc on your enemies during action-packed fight sequences.  Additionally, the XP and skill-point system will keep you goal-oriented and allow you to unlock new abilities as you play to keep things fresh.For those itching for more after beating the main campaign, there is also an entirely separate Co-op Mode, which expands upon the universe of The Darkness II and allows for multiplayer gameplay.  Fortunately, all the missions in the Co-op Mode can be completed in solo play if you don’t want to spend time trying to find others to play with.  While not quite as pristine as the main campaign, it adequately provides some supplementary gameplay to a game that would otherwise be only medium-length (in terms of total hours).In summary, I posit that The Darkness II is a superb all-around game with many positive elements contributing to its overall quality.  I would say it is a pretty safe bet for most gamers who have a broad taste for games, and a definite safe bet for those gamers who enjoy FPS games and interesting narratives.  Expect about 6-18 hours of gameplay, depending on how much of a “completionist” you are.  If you can get it for a price you are comfortable with, it is definitely worth the pick-up.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

												It doesn't take you long to be pulled into the story. The Darkness 2 does a great job of immersing you into the feelings and thoughts of the main character, which is a rarity in modern day gaming. Often you are very disconected from the story and the emotions of the characters. Lately, the only other game I have played that did such a great job of pulling you in, emotionally, was BioShock Infinite.Beyond the story, which while nothing especially impressive, what is there is enough and is well orcestrated. The most impressive feat is the game's ability to put you in the shoes of the main character and really doubt what is real and what is not real (in the game).The gameplay is top notch though and if you enjoy shooters where you run from one area to the next and have to clear all the waves of enemies, then this is a game for you. The gunplay is fun and has impact and the tentacles are well implemented so that they are not overpowered and yet are still very fun and exciting to use.

												The Darkness 2Rating 8/10Overview: Underrated First Person ShooterThe Good:+ Cell shaded graphics + The game has a strong narrative which holds the game together otherwise it would turn into a mindless shooter. Although the plot itself is pretty basic the developers did a great job of presenting the story. The characters may be stereotypical of what you would expect in a mafia however it doesn't take away the fact they are believable and expertly voiced.   + The game features a variety of guns which is what you would expect from any first person shooter however the twist in this game is that you have two demonic arms, one for picking/throwing objects and the other as a high powered melee weapon. You can also execute enemies in some pretty horrific ways.  + Speaking of gratuitous violence, it works well in this game. Most games have over the top violence just for the sake of it yet I feel this game really nailed this particular aspect, it really sells the notion that you are possessed by dark forces.  + Killing enemies and collecting relics in the levels allows you to level up different skills among 4 skill trees. + New Game + allows you to replay the game with all your acquired skills + Easy Achievements, minimal grinding required. + Great voice acting+ Good soundtrack The Average: On the one hand the game is short, roughly 5-7 hours in length. On the other hand the game isn't bogged down with pointless filler either, the game does what it wants to without over extending its welcome. After you complete the main story, you can try the vendetta campaign, an add on to extend your playtime. You can choose between 4 characters, each with their own weapon, skill trees and powers. You can also play co-op with friends. The problem however is that every level becomes very repetitive of killing wave after wave of enemy. The formula wears itself out very early on. This mode is also very short , roughly 2-3 hours in length. The Bad:- Multiplayer is dead  ConclusionIt was a sequel that didn't need to be made but in the end it turned out to be a great game to a very underappreciated game franchise. A fun distraction while it lasts and nothing more. Strongly recommend at a discount price.

												Linear action FPS game with a lot of violence, blood and vulgarity. Basically it's like playing a horror game but YOU ARE THE HORROR!What I love most about this game is the story-telling, the narrative of the game. All the characters in this game have their own personality, even the crazy ones! The person who voiced Johnny Powell is a genius!There is a multiplayer mode called the "Vandette". It has a number of co-op missions that you can play solo or play with up to 4 players online. Each playable characters have their own personality and their own dialogues as well! The multiplayer campaign fills in the holes in the single player story very well. This is one of the rarer games where the multiplayer mode actually adds value to the single player story-telling.The artsy graphics adds a lot of nostalgic feel to the game environment. This type of graphics rendering method also brilliantly mask away a lot of disgust from the bloody violence where it would be gross if rendered too realistically.If you are the reading type and like to understand as much of the game world as possible, you can learn a lot from reading the relics origin. The game universe is based a lot closely to our real world religions, with a little fictional element added into it. And it makes a lot of sense! (On top of that, it has the funny narration from the crazy genius!)It has moderate replay value. Once you are done with the single player campaign, you can replay the campaign with new game plus to learn more about the game setting and to hunt for collectibles. But it's only worth 2-3 playthrus before it gets repetitive. Multiplayer have quite a number of maps but since multiplayer characters have very limited skillset, it gets repetitive very soon.All the achievements are quite doable in single player, 100% completion is not difficult.My Score: 10/10 (Highly recommended!)

												I doubt that you have ever heard of 2006's console exclusive the Darkness or the comic books published by Top Cow Productions (yes, that's the actual name... I couldn't make that one up) of the same name, so let me tell you a little bit about the unpopular The Darkness II.Or The Darkness 2 if you don't know your Roman numerals. If you don't, shame on you.In The Darkness II you play as Jackie Estacado, a member of the Franchetti crime family. He was adopted by the former Don of the Franchetti's, Frankie Franchetti at the age of six and matured quickly; he lost his virginity to a female officer durning an investigation at the age of fourteen and killed his first victim at the age of sixteen. His presence in the Franchetti family helped it to expand, as predicted by the mysterious Sonatine.When Jackie turned twenty-one, he revieved the powers of the Darkness, a timeless power allowing the Host to form basically anything out of darkness (for example, the Arms) that will crumble to dust in the light. To keep it short, lots of sh*t hit the fan in a short period of time, causing his true love Jenny to be killed. Years passed since then, and Jackie forced himself to keep the Darkness locked up inside of him after blaming it for Jenny's death. That's where the second game begins and the Darkness gets unleashed again.Sound interresting? Well trust me, it IS interresting.The Good:· Very solid shooter mechanics.· An upgrade-system that will make you feel more powerful as the game progresses.· You can control Jackie's sentient demon arms to grab enemies and objects and perform brutal finishing moves. (For example splitting a guy clean in half or ripping someone's spine out of his sh*tter. I know. His f*cking sh*tter. They just rip that open harder than Kim Kardashian's c*nt.)· A surprisingly personal and meaningful story that will keep you interrested until the very end.· The Darkness 2 plays with light in a unique way - standing in light will blind you and make you more volnurable, but being in the darkness makes you brutally strong.The Bad:· The co-op missions can easily be forgotten.· Besides tha campaign, collectibles and co-op the game offers too little content to keep you coming back to it.· Unfortunately unsuccesful, meaning that the chances of a third installment is highly unlikely.The Ugly:While the comicbook-esque and gore-filled visuals are a joy to look at, there's nothing too stunning about it. It never looks bad, but it doesn't look as good as it could have.Final verdict:This is a title I will always remember for its dark and unique setting, plus it's one of the forgotten "good comicbook games" out there that needs to be played, simply because it's an thrilling experience. 8.5/10

												You can skip to the bottom of the review for the TL;DRThe Darkness 2 is one of my personal favourites in a long list of games on my steam account. It is everything you could possibly want from a first person shooter that has a noire feeling to it, with light horror elements and an interesting story that will keep you hooked.The story, without spoiling anything, is a direct sequel for the first part, meaning eveything ties up and the timelines are logical. Basically: you are Jackie Estacado, a young mafia member with dark powers beyond control,that seeks vengeance.The plot gets better and makes more sense as you play through the game. You have choices, tough it's not a primary element of the game and the story and levels are rather linear, choices only representing the question "do you want one more cutscene?", most of the times.The gameplay is where this game really excels at. You have the basic fps mechanics with a strong emphasis on the signature dual wield of Jackie, which can carry 3 weapons with him- a primary, a secondary and another secondary, with the option to dual the secondaries or carefully aim with them. Besides that, the power of the darkness system is truly a breath of fresh air for the genre. Jackie has, at all times, 2 demon arms besides him that, if controlled right, can do huge amounts of damage just on their own. Tactically combined with the generic fps mechanics, they can adapt to any situation and turn the tides of battle in a second with specific skills. They can slash, execute enemies in exchange for health, ammo, etc, grab objects from the enviroment to use them as either defense or gory offense. Your godly powers go away in the light tough, as the game offers dynamic light gameplay elements, requiring you to think strategically before encounters as you shoot lights out and cut down heads.The game also has a skill tree system, featuring 4 different skill trees that all branch out from a primary ability and that can be leveled simultaneously. The primary skill adds a new mechanic, eating the hearts of enemies (dead ones, of course) and replinishing health by it and gaining more points towards the purchase of your next skill. Every skill tree has a speciality and any skill you get can drastically change the gameplay and your methods of brutally murdering bad guys, making the end game the most fun of all, as you got so many tools in your arsenal that every situation is your playground. The skills you get also scale with your own, as you learn to further multitask the demon arms while still keeping concentrated on the basic firefights and making the ultimate killing machine out of you. That's why even the hardest difficulty doesn't feel unfair in any way, but challenging and forcing you to sharpen those reflexes make use of everything you learn. It's a masterpiece to be quite honest with you. Just so you can get the idea of how deep this game can be (story-wise), before the TL;DR, I'll leave you with my favourite monologue of Jackie Estacado: "Time slips away from you. And then, all of a sudden, it's like you're sitting in a theatre, watching a movie of your own life. You're a fu**ing movie star. And you're killing all the bad guys-tearing them limb from limb.And you feel good, you look good. F**k, you ARE good. And then you realize something: everyone else in the theatre? They're screaming, because they're watching a horror movie...and you're not the hero...you're the monster..."TL;DR: A great atmospheric game, filled with gore and overall dark themes. One of the best story-driven first person shooters out there, featuring great, complex and innovative gameplay mechanics by using the power of the darkness. A solid 10/10 in my opinion, at least for the singleplayer.

												The Darkness II is a fun arcade shooter with a bunch of supernatural abilities thrown into the mix. The graphics are bright and cartoonish, similar to 2K Games' more popular game Borderlands, and don't tax a modern gaming PC overmuch. Unfortunately, there is no option to disable depth of field, which is not to everyone's taste.The gameplay is varied, enabling you to deploy different tactics ranging from brutal executions using your extra demon snake arms and impaling people with thrown parking meters to channelling the darkness into your guns as you shred the enemies stunned by your swarms of demonic flies.Controls are fair, but your demon arms suffer from a complete inability to multitask, preventing you from, for example, eating the hearts of fallen enemies to regain health while simultaneously holding a makeshift javelin or a shield at the ready, because such petty concerns are beneath your right hand, which is only used for striking. The game also assumes that if you have a gamepad connected to your PC, you will only be using it, refusing to stop vibrating it and displaying gamepad-centric button prompts even if you play the game using the keyboard and mouse exclusively, so be prepared to have to unplug or disable your gamepad if you prefer keyboard and mouse.The story is a little on the short side, but the co-op enabled side missions called "Vendettas" make up for it. The world is well-designed and some of the dialogue is very funny if you take the time to listen to it. The game gives you the ability to skip most cutscenes and dialogue, enabling you to replay the campaign without having to wait for things you have already seen.As for bugs, there is a couple annoying ones: turning vertical sync on will sometimes cause the screen to blur for long periods of time, while turning it off will prevent you from moving through a few tight spaces. If you're affected by either bug, toggle vertical sync on or off.Given that the game often goes on very deep sales (85% off), there's little reason not to buy it if you enjoy FPS games.

Posted: July 15, 2015
Darkness 2 is without a doubt one of the best shooters from 2012.Why ? It's unique, fresh, fun, beautiful and content packed. It has two separate campaigns, hit list missions, 5 playable characters etc etc...Single-player: You play as Jackie Estacado, head of the Franchetti crime family. You "wield" the Darkness. Darkness allows you to slash, grab, throw and execute enemies. It also allows you to grab different objects and throw them at your enemies.Jackie has 5 different skill trees that allow you to unlock and acquire new executions, abilities/skills and upgrades.You can also dual wield different types of weapons. An example: You can carry and fire a Desert Eagle and an MP7 at the same time - Darkness 2 gives the word "badass" a whole new meaning.Everything you see can be used as a weapon tho. Just grab a pipe and throw it at your enemies!The single-player campaign is only 5-6 hours long (don't worry, there is enough content in the game) but that's a good thing. It doesn't drag it out. The story is great and it never gets boring. A lot of games make the mistake of dragging the game out just to try to be a bit longer. Not this one! You're always focused on the main goal and the story is addictive and interesting. There's also New Game+ that allows you to play through the game while keeping all your unlocked abilities. A good way to unlock all five skilltrees.Co-op: Co-op adds another 2-3 hours long campaign (1-4 players, can also be played and finished alone in offline mode), 6 solo and 2-player "Hit List" missions and 4 new characters: Shoshanna, Inugami, JP DuMond and Jimmy Wilson.Each character has different and unique special weapons, one-liners, executions and 3 different skill trees - you can tell that developers put a lot of time and hard work into making these characters...into making this game!Shoshanna wields a super-shotgun that never misses. Inugami carries a katana with him (felt like playing Shadow Warrior), Jimmy has an axe and JP carries a magical staff that lets him lift enemies. Each also has 3 different skill trees, executions and one-liners.Yes, there are one-liners in this game! The single-player campaign is rather dark and serious but the co-op campaign takes itself a lot less seriously. It's a bit silly, funny and with all these one-liners it feels like playing Duke or Shadow Warrior! It's a lot of fun!The gameplay is unique and makes this game stand out from the others. It has an awesome story, an interesting setting, a great artstyle and the graphics are quite good aswell. It has a lot of content and in my opinion it's well worth the full price.8/10 - A must have for all FPS fans! Especially if you can get a friend to buy and play the co-op with you.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												**UPDATE** Still THE BEST Story game I have ever played. I literally recommend it to everyone that is wanting a story game. After getting 100% on it, I should probably make a review of it. The Darkness 2 is an extremely violent FPS with a storyline that twists and turns and gives you even more addiction at the end game. This is one of the better storylines that I have ever played and it gives you all the feels in all the right ways. You get joy, revenge, sadness, vengance, longing, and all those other characteristics to be able to relate with everyone in the game. The Darkness was an interesting concept because it isn't a voice that is just narrating you or such. It is a part of you and influences you. It doesn't tell you to go here or there, it screams at you that your will obey it and it taunts you with a lost soul it controls. The boss fights in the game are pretty solid, the bosses have enough mobility to where you can't just stand there and shoot at them in one direction. They move a lot and most of the time you have to be moving as well. The light concept is very well done and brings more aspects of thinking ahead and getting priorities out (especially in the harder difficulties). If you are under a light source your screen goes white where you can barely see and being in the light removes your powers and any buffs that you have acquired that only apply when you are in the dark. So when a van comes crushing through towards you, you should probably shoot out the headlights first before trying to fend off the enemies. The execution moves are super brutal. There are 4 different executions that you can do and each results in a different buff and also a different execution style. You can either use the execution to restore health, restore ammo, gain a demonic riot shield, or shorten you skills timers. Each I believe have 3 different executions resulting in 12 total executions which all have their own amount of brutality for anyone to enjoy. There is enough of a talent tree to make you play more than one run through and probably just move on to Don difficulty at that point. You can do New Game+ to keep all your talents and such, which makes a considerable amount of Don difficulty pretty easy, but bosses still can be hard to beat. I know that some people didn't really like the graphics of the game, but I believe they probably made them that way because of the Borderlands series, both are made by 2K games, so I think that is what they did, but in my own opinion I love the graphics as do I love Borderlands, so it was enjoyable for me. The NPCs in the game all have a certain human flair to them where they aren't just NPCs, you can relate to them easily and they become much more than just NPCs. You collect relics throughout the game that will give you essence (which is gained by killing people, getting relics, and is used to buy talents) and they aren't that hard to find. Some are easy to miss but generally you won't have problems finding them. The weapon selection through the game is pretty small, but they made it for a good reason. There aren't any snipers or rocket launchers or big weapons like that, no grenades either (unless you count throwing propane tanks XD ). with the smaller weapons, you can either weild one at a time, or dual weild. The choices are for single shots: Desert Eagle, Cobra, and M9. The choices are for automatics: UMP5, MP7, and Micro UZI. The choices are for the main weapon: Carbine (M16 Burst Fire), AK47, Sawed Off Shotgun, Model 1887 (?), and a Stiker. The powers you have through the game is also limited, but they are super powerful so it doesn't really matter at that point honestly. You have two activated abilities, The Swarm and Gun Channeling. The Swarm goes out and swarms around people effectively stunning them (and sometimes even killing them), you can get upgrades for it to last longer, recharge faster and affect more enemies. Gun Channgeling gives you infinite ammo and super powered shots for a limited time. The upgrades consits of longer lasting, faster recharge, auto shooting towards targets and shooting through walls. So as you can tell, turning a corridor full of enemies you can just activate both and blow through them both in two seconds. I didn't really find any bugs in the game. The only real problem I had is that sometimes the screen goes a little blurry, like the beginning of being of barely stepping in light and it just causes some depth of view problems. It doesn't really last long if it happens, but it can and when you are trying to fight people it messes with your vision a bit. So all in all to say: 10/10 hands down. Would love to have harder achievements though.

												The Darkness II:This is the second Steam account that I have owned The Darkness II on so before you look at my time played and say "You haven't played through it", I have. I've played through the entire game multiple times.First and foremost, this is the most underrated game on Steam. That's why I voted for The Darkness II for the "I Thought This Game was Cool Before it Won an Award" award.One major complaint that I have about The Darkness II is how short its campaign is. It's not difficult to beat it in around six hours. That might sound a little disappointing compared to its predecessor's much longer runtime, it's really not that bad. If you were to cut out the first game's mundane side missions and mindless wandering around the labyrinthine city and the subway tunnels below it, both games would be about the same length. I don't know about you, but I'd much rather have six incredible hours of gameplay than twelve mediocre hours with a few good parts thrown in.There are four characters you can choose from, and their unique skill trees and Darkness weapons make each of them worth checking out. There's Inugami, a swordsman who has to kill to satiate his cursed katana lest it take his soul; a Scotsman named Jimmy Wilson, who has a love for the drink and a fondness for splitting skulls with an axe; a voodoo shaman named JP Dummond, who wields a powerful staff; and Shoshanna, who gets up close and personal with her double-barrel shotgun. None of them are particularly relatable characters, but they're all solid, and their unique weapons and skill sets offer some incentive to play through Vendettas more than once. That's a good thing though because the mode only takes a few hours to complete.The Darkness II is everything I wanted a sequel to The Darkness to be. It's almost excessive in its violence, the combat is addicting, the hand-drawn Graphic Noir art style is gorgeous, and underneath it all is a game with a heart and a truly interesting story. Jackie's a supremely messed-up individual, but I still love him because of all the stuff he's willing to go through in order to save Jenny. If you're looking for any of these things, The Darkness II won't disappoint.

Teal DeerDevelopers: Digital Extremes Publishers: 2K gamesInitial release: Feb 2012Genre: FPS, Action, Crime #Worth/NotWorth: #WorthExposition, Concurrence and SummationThe Darkness II is a shooter that continues the story from the first game. Though to be fair you need not have played it to at least have a basic understanding of what is happening. You play as Jackie Estacado who has become the don of the Franchetti crime family. Reluctant to use his powers granted to him by the Darkness lest they influence him too greatly; In the events occurring in the introduction he is forced to embrace them once again. The Darkness gives Jackie demonic powers in that from a gameplay perspective results in more or less having two extra arms. However the extra arms are more like demonic snakes than regular human arms. You can duel wield rifles, grab and slash with your tentacles; throw piping and impale people into walls. Rip car doors off and use them as a shield; before it gives out in usefulness whip it at someone and slice them in half. Basically anything you want or feel like you should be able to do as a character with ostensibly four arms, you can. And it all feels really good and smooth. The guns feel powerful and so do the arms. The animations are extremely gore-filled. With help from the leveling tree you can earn health regen and ammo recoup from specific animations as well as more basic things like faster reload or increased ammo capacity. Feeding the darkness the hearts of falling enemies doesn't really get old. Aesthetically, the game is rather pleasing, featuring a cel shaded/comic book representation of its visual assets. The single player Campaign is rather short (around 5 hours) but it doesn't over stay it's welcome. The game also has some co-op missions in the form of Vendetta missions. These can be played solo or up to four players. Honestly, it has a little bit of a Left 4 Dead vibe to it. Sort of arena with some traditional level design for preamble. There are characters to play as rather than classes. Notably, the one that stood out to me was the shaman. Voiced by none other than Dave Fennoy, though I think he sounded a bit like the character Lee from TellTales The Walking Dead which I believe to be the closet to his real voice (turns out, he is like Nolan North, Tara Strong, Troy Baker level amount of prominence, I had no idea.) The actor who does the voice of the darkness is also extremely talented; Mike Patton, an in-studio example of his voice can be seen/heard here. These phenomenal voice actors make the story telling that much better. THE GISTReally fluid, dynamic and fun shooter with a story and visual art style that will keep you interested throughout.Follow my curation for more

												Love story written in blood. Spiced up by powers of Darkness, flying bodies, torn corpses, severed limbs and tasty headshots. Great voice acting (all chars, but the main hero [Brian Bloom] and Darkness [Mike Patton] especially. The last scream of the main character is so freaking real.), excellent music (listen to it for a while) and graphical style. Graphics and sounds are nice as well. Gameplay - well... no sane person wants to be your enemy - quad wielding allows for 2 weapons and 2 hellish tentacles to massacre the enemies. You plow through the bad guys. Wiping out baddies is very satysfying. SP story is good (it is weird as well at times, but in a good way). There are few "WTF" moments. There are some emotional moments which I found to fit the atmosphere perfectly and I loved them in game. They did not feel out of place for sure.Coop is great - 18 missions for max 4 players. There are 4 different chars, each with his/her own skills and weapons. Coop takes place in paralell to story which is nice since they overlap in events. I sank in this game. I played and maxed every character I could. Gamplay is fluent and very satysfying. Underrated and underestimated game. Shame. Definitely worth attention! I just wish the first game made it to PC - it did not and it never will, so enjoy this one.PC port and performance are solid. FOV slider is in the game :D. Too bad ini files are encrypted as it limits tweaking because Unreal Engine 3 is pretty flexible. Get.This.Game!

												NOTE: I have not played The Darkness 1. So my review can't compare the two games, I have however read the comic and know what happens, so my knowledge of the story is pretty decent.A fan of The Darkness comic book, I picked up this game a while ago in a humble bundle, and really just didn't like the idea of having the demon arms and everything in the game. In fact, I would have ended up never playing it if I hadn't felt a commitment to the comics.I decided to just play a single level this morning and actually found it fairly boring at first. The gameplay just seemed to be far too easy and the storyline was not what I had hoped for considering the excellent comic it was based on. I decided to play another level just to see if the game would pick up.I ended up completing the game without stopping. It's amazing.The gameplay works far better than I imagined. The demon arms are not tedious to use, and are not as overpowered as I felt they were in the first mission. Even without the demon arms, this would be a pretty solid FPS. However these of course add a unique twist on the game to seperate it from the countless other first person shooters available right now.The storyline is fantastic for a AAA game. (I don't know if its a ''AAA'' game as it's release wasnt absolutely huge...Let's call it a ''AA''.)If I am completely honest, the gameplay does get slightly repetitive. However this combined with the other flaw which is that the game is far too short, mean that you don't get bored of the game that easily as it's finished before you can get tiresome.I don't feel like there's much replay value here unfortunately.Final Verdict:+Fantastic storyline.+Entertaining gameplay+Interesting use of demonic powers at the same time as guns. Something completely refreshing.- Game is far too short-Can become slightly repetitive towards the end. (However storyline gets more intense towards the end so you don't notice this so much.)8/10

Posted: November 14, 2016
												One of the best modern FPS I've played . Characters are well thought out & relationships are warm, story is good, game looks nice (suits it's comic book origin), gameplay is smooth & fun, music is servicable, & it has a nice sense of humour. Special attacks & Death animations are satisfying and short enough to never get boring. Your AI partner is useful & charming, urinating & farting on enemy corpses in a hilarious fashion. Also, great details such as reports on the radios regarding your last murder spree, and some optional dialouges & mini games scattered around the game adds more depth as well as change things up a bit.Negatives for me involved* the comparatively SUPER LOUD logo section which starts off the game. Watch your ear drums! * The "stuck in vents"-bug, which was solved by enabling v-synch in the menu, for some reason. If anyone can explain in simpel terms how that works, please do so! I can't understand how something like vertical synch would make your character be able to walk across inviseable walls?* The really annoying "blurred vision" bug, which is solved by taking screen shots. It occured more frequently for me as the game went along. Perhaps the more enemies on screen the worse the blur got? It shouldn't really be a problem for me with the specs of my PC, but there you go.* The "never stops firing" bug, which is solved by switching weapon.* The "thump sound bug" which doesn't affect anything really except for inducing mild annoyance in the gamer, just a weird noise that keeps repeating itself a bit moment after certain actions.Exra bonus for having several different female character models; slim, fat, "normal", older, younger etc, and not sexualising the main love interest but staying respectfully true of the protaganists own feelings for her. She was shown in casual clothes in the majority fo the game, plain in appearance but heavily emphasized to be a caring and fun loving individual. Though many of your companions are sexist♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you are not, and you get the feeling the game aims to portrait sexism & "masculine" violence as a bad thing, and respect as a good one. Especially in how the game depicts a brothel, which is one of the saddest & most thought provoking enviroments I've come across in gaming.Some have complained about the game being too short in lenght, but I thought it was just right, especially for a follow up second playhtrough in game mode + (being able to keep your xp and collectibles). I tend to get too stressed about longer games to even play them to begin with, so this was just perfect in my opinion.Seeing as this game is at the publication of this review 4, almost 5, years old, it is most definetly worth it's price on sale if nothing else.

												The Darkness 2 is fun, brutal, and stays quite faithul to it's source material, in terms of both its story and its visual presentation. It offers a multitude of ways to brutally murder your opponents- if its guns are not enough for you, you'll find much to do with the Darkness' serpents, whipping, slashing, eviscerating your foes. So, if the gunplay is good, the melee is good, the story is good, what's the catch?Well, the catch is, there's not much of it.I completed this game, from blood soaked beginning to somber end, in five hours. Now, it is true that the New Game + adds a touch more length to the game, and the four player cooperative mode fills in the gaps in between the main story, but, again, there's just not that much of it to go around! So, would I purchase this game at thirty dollars, which is the standard asking price? No. I mean, I kind of already did, but as warning to any of you who are new to the series, unless you've got thirty bucks you're in desperate need of not spending on possible bundles of longer, cheaper titles with more replayability, no.But if you're reading this during a sale, this game is worth every last penny as long as you have a buddy to share the ride with- it's phenomenal on the whole, and I wish they would either make a sequel or port the first game to PC.

Posted: July 11, 2016
												While I never played the first "The Darkness" (I haven't owned a console for two gens now) I played the demo for The Darkness II and was very impressed by the art style and the beautiful gore.The game places you in the boots of Jackie Estacado, the current head of the Italian mafia who happens to be in possession of "The Darkness" which he has to keep at bay. Needless to say shortly after the game starts Jackie IS forced to call upon the powers of The Darkness  to save himself and wreck havoc on those who wronged him. Where this game excels is in combat. In addition to the usual range of guns you have The Darkness on your side: two gross tentacles that grow out of your back (or shoulders, it's hard to tell). This adds a great layer of depth to an otherwise very good first person shooter. Gun mechanics are great if a little arcade-y. Having the tentacles on your side means you have access to far reaching melee attacks that dispatch enemies in a gloriously gruesome fashion (note, if you are squeamish, stay away, this game is very VERY gruesome. I'm talking people being torn in half, split in half, ripped in half, disemboweled, etc.).Outside of the combat is some truly great storytelling that utilizes the "unreliable narrator" mechanic I learned about in English class VERY well. I won't spoil anything but you will be guessing probably right up until the end as to what is really going on in the story. The voice acting is great (as long as you don't hate Italian-American accents) and the dialogue is very well written. I found myself very surprised at the overall production value and quality that the game reeked of.In regards to achievements, this one was pretty easy. There were some in there that were fun to try and tackle and provided satisfaction but it's mostly story mode on different difficulties and collectibles plus a few "do this a certain way" (which are the ones I dig). I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes a good FPS with a great story (even if it is linear). It's not too long of a game but I would consider it just the right length considering what you get. For achievement hunters I say go for it. It wasn't too tricky to 100% and nothing stands out in my memory as something that was broken or near-impossible.Overall, if you're a fan of First-Person Shooter games you can't go wrong with this title. You can usually get it cheap these days and there's no DLC to worry about buying to complete it. Highly recommended.8/10

												Note: to see this review with pictures,etc go to: {LINK REMOVED}http://tinyurl.com/TheDarknessGeekofwildoowd-comThe Darkness 2, is a Canadian developed first-person shooter psychological horror game by Digital Extremes and published by 2K GamesIn the Darkness 2 Jackie Estacado - the players character, has taken over one of New Yorks biggest Gang/Mob. still suffering from regret over his girlfriends death, Jackie is trying to live a normal life. having learned how to control and repress The Darkness. but he is forced to unleash The Darkness after a strange cult attacks him and his friends.To be honest,The Darkness 2 is petty cliche, Guy loves girl, girl gets killed, guy has flash backs of said dead gril, on and on, you get the point. the levels aren't breathtaking, or special. no, in fact most of it is a hallway shooter and it really never breaks that form. despite all this the game is still fun. and the reason is of The Darkness. you get to use this special power and its pretty fun to take out enemy with it.but you will soon tire of seeing the same kill moves over and over and over. sure, the first time or so its pretty cool to watch, but by the 30th or 40th time of seen the same kill moves you'll get bored. still, later on in the Darkness 2, the story does get better, and it will sometimes have you wondering what is real and what is not.alas, the world of The Darkness 2 is boring and dry. almost all of the gameplay takes place in dark alleys/buildings that are extremely generic. and just to be more cliche The Darkness 2 features a abandoned fair/circus.in the end The Darkness 2 is nothing special, but it is fun the first few times you play it. even the gameplay suffers though. as on normal the game is only four hours. The Darkness 2 has a multiplayer mode, however its boring and dull. the Darkness is worth 15$ max and you will have some fun with it. but once you get done with the story you will probably never play it again.

-Quick Review-The Darkness II is a FPS with a lot of unique mechanics that I've only experienced for the first time in playing a game  with this  genre (grabbing stuff with tentacles, using them to heal yourself, I can hear a bad hentai joke coming...)


YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: The Darkness II 

			Views: 143		

			The Darkness 2 is a FPS story driven game available here: Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/67370/ HomePage: http://www.embracethedarkness.com/us/ The Song during the Story section of The...		

-Detailed breakdown review-Story:  You play the game as Jackie, a gruff, angry, imposing man whom has a dark power that he inherited from his father. Tormented by his memory of his girl friend Jenny he struggles to try to get revenge for an attempt on his life.I found it amusing that the game basically makes Jackie a crime boss, it game the game and the story an interesting tone. And the game carried it very well. The story was extremely well executed down to the very end of the game. I don't want to give anymore away, I will say that the game lets you select an introduction that explains what happened in the first Darkness game, if you (like me) never played the first game.Game Play: while I was playing I was confused at the key mapping from the start of the game, but I picked up on the controls really quickly, like I've said I've only played the easiest difficulty so I just hack and slashed my way through the whole game and didn't die once.There are a few main combat mechanics: 1) you use guns. Hence why I categorize it as a FPS 2) You have two shadow arms that wreak havoc with basic swing attacks 3) your shadow arms can grab and throw objects 4) your arms can grab other humans and mutilate them to gain ammo, health, amusement, etc.By combining these various moves and abilities you can create some really awesome combination attacks. If you're aware of your surroundings and have good reflexes the game is really fun to play. I get tired of playing the same type of game over and over, but this game takes a great spin on traditional FPS's and gives it interesting mechanics to make the game just that much more interesting and engaging.One more note on game play: Progression. I find that just killing hundreds of npc's for the sake of killing npc's isn't very interesting *cough cough* Brutal Legend *cough cough*. Anyway, the game has a level system that you can spent points to get new abilities, making that mass slaughter I had, actually have a purpose. Achievements: As usual this game has the standard "you beat the game" achievements. The "beat the game on this difficulty" achievements. there are also a few multiplayer achievements (which I haven't worked on yet), And then there are the "do this special thing in the game".The achievements seem straightforward. But I haven't earned them all yet (08/09/14) so I don't know if there are any really note worthy achievements at this time. but so far the achievements look very straightforward.Price: The Darkness II is $29.99, at this time I've only put 5 hours into the game, but I can see myself  playing this game for about 10-20 hours. I really enjoyed the game, but I don't know how high the replay value is for someone whom isn't going for achievements.I really enjoyed the story, and don't have anything really negative to say about the game (other than at time the gore was a bit much, but that won't bother most people), as I usually say at this point, is that I'd recommend getting this game in a Humble Bundle or waiting for it to go on sale. I personally purchased mine in a Humble Bundle.  Conclusion: to recap,  the story was excellent, the game play was engaging and interesting, the achievements were alright, the price was kind of high but the quality in the game was good. I recommend this game to anyone who knows they know FPS's, don't mind gore, like a bit of a darker story (pun not intended), and likes a good story.Edit/Update 08/16/14I have a few things to add about the game. I've all but earned all the achievements on this game. So in a way I've given a bit of a preview of how much work it takes to get the various achievements. The game has actually gotten better.I played through the Vendetta's, which is a multi-player element to the game. But you also have the option of solo-playing through the whole thing. You have access two 4 new characters that run a "side quest line" parallel to what is happening to Jackie in the main story. This element gives the game more replay-quality, which for me is great! I love continuing to work through a game after I've beaten it, and have a different experience.A quick updated note about the achievements: Most of the achievements aren't very difficult, but actually require you to try out different things in the game. I didn't find myself particularly frustrated with any of them. This game actually had an almost-perfect balance in their achievements for my tastes.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update October 29, 2016:Added the video review from my YouTube Channel.

Unleash the darkness and kill your foes with tentacles... Hm, kinky.The Darkness II is a 3rd person shooter based on the comics from the 90ties. You play as Jack Estacado, a mafia chief who is possessed by an entity known as "The Darkness", which gives you super powers but makes you follow its will.GameplayAs a single player FPS you will be shooting hordes of enemies with your guns. You got many guns such as shotguns, assault rifles, pistols, revolvers... You also got a pair of demoniac tentacles that can slice enemies and do crazy stuff, like throwing objects and performing some "fatalities" on the enemies. You dont have regenerative health or medickits, to restore health you need to use your tentacles to literaly eat the heart of dead enemies. Also to recover ammo just grab the gun of a dead enemy. Gameplay is blazing fast: you will be surrounded by enemies and will start shooting like crazy and chopping them off with you tentacles. Game is very gory and violent, not recommended for the faint of heart...StoryTrying to avoid spoilers here. Basically you have some evil guys who want to take the "Darkness" from you and use it for their own evil pourposes. The Darkness wants to overcome the threat and uses the souls of your dead girlfriend Jenny as a way to persuade you into obeying it. The story is really well constructed and has some good plot twists near the end. I mean, the game gives you a lot more than just enemies to shoot, it gives a good and and entertaining dark comic book time.I Rate it 3.8/5.0, its good, but kinda repetitive with the infinite hordes of the same mobs you fight over and over...

												Short: 8/10 Fun shooter with ~17 hours of (offline) gameplay.Long: The Darkness 2 is a first person shooter with RPG elements like a talent tree and special action skills (think Borderlands) as well as point awards for combos (think Call of Juarez). The game guides you into the sequel via short monologue, explaning the plot of the first game thus getting you right on board. Gameplay is very easy to pick up and fun throughout; utilising kill combos, dual wield gun play, special active skills or your darkness "tentacles". The enemies vary for about 3/4 of the game so just when you start getting a little tired of them, it's mostly over. The replay value comes via New Game+ mode as well as several online/offline co-op side missions. The side missions aren't anything special and killing the same enemies gets a bit tiresome, but the characters have their own talent trees and voice acting, which somewhat makes up for it. All in all it's a good shooter romp that has good replay value (as you can see by my 50/50 achievement score). It doesn't bring anything ground breaking into the shooter genre but it doesn't try to and knows its strong points. 8/10 for me.

However, the teleporting enemies and whip soldiers get to be somewhat of a chore and there is an unfortunate propensity towards gamebreaking glitches in areas that will require multiple reloads before they manage to right themselves. We're 5 years down the line and still no sign of a sequel. I can see why they ended it the way they did, but if a sequel happening was entirely dependent on sales, then they should've made it a conclusive ending. That said, this is likely why the option to either let the credits run or go back is present, so we can either have a complete story or a cliffhanger depending on your whim.A worthwhile game but unfortunately afflicted with problems that should really be addressed, especially after this long. If nothing else it needs to be patched.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
Short versionIf you like FPS games in general Darkness II is a good choice, and if you're a fan of Top Cow comics, then it's a must buy.Long versionThe Darkness 2 is a FPS based on the highly successful comic series published by Top Cow.You play as Jackie Estacado, leader of a New York mafia and the current host of the Darkness, an ancient force that's been passed down from generation to generation in the Estacado family.(Note: The Darkness is one of the 3 ancient entities in the Top Cow universe, the other 2 being the Angelus - pure light- and the Witchblade - balance between light and dark.)The game picks up where the prequel ended: Jenny, Jackie's lover is dead, and the mourning Jackie has repressed the Darkness. But when a mysterious organization, The Brotherhood is planning on eliminating Jackie and his organization and take the Darkness from him, he has no choice but to use the Darkness again to save himself. Sounds cheesy, I know.The game features a quad-wielding system, which means you can wield 2 different weapons, while the 2 demonic tendrils can be used to grab objects to shield yourself, or throw, or to execute enemies.As the host of the Darkness, Jackie has access to large variety of demonic abilites, however becoming vulnerable and blinded when exposed to light. This adds interesting elements to the gameplay: as you kill enemies you gain darkness essense, which can be used to learn new skills, becoming extremely strong. While Jackie's weakness to the light still forces the player to take cover and take out light sources constantly. The game has good looking cel-shaded graphics, and there's enough variety in the level designs to keep the player entertained throughout the story. Although the game doesn't have huge levels, hence not much exploration and the secrets can be found fairly easy too.Overall The Darkness II is a good FPS game, with solid gameplay and an interesting story with some psychological elements and a nice plot twist in the end, that imply a possible sequel.  PROS- Nice looking cell-shaded graphics.- 2 parallel campaigns: a single player storyline and a co-op campaign, showing the plot from different point of view.- Psychological aspect of the story.- Memorable characters. - Good variety of abilities.- Excellent voice acting.- Large arsenal, ranging from firearms, through various projectiles to Darkness abilities.CONS- Extremely short, and sometimes painfully cheesy story.- Not challanging enough: game can be beaten fairly easy even on highest difficulty.- Execution animations are glitchy sometimes.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												TIME TO COMPLETE: 11.5 hoursTIME TO COMPLETE ACHIEVEMENTS: 19.2 hoursAlthough I started with the second, it is a shame that the first Darkness game wasn't ported to PC. Linear and handholding at the beggining, The Darkness II tells the story of Jackie Estacado, now the head of a mob familiy after his father's death. A lot of things, new and old, were brought together in an orderly fashion. The things that only fans of the series (a.k.a those who read the comics) would understand were summed up in a nice, compact way while still giving justice to the series.The campaign was short and it had its flaws but the story compensated. Jackie is a likeable character although many of his insults and macabre jokes from the comics were removed. The controls are clunky at first but they fit to the pacing of the game. There's also a single Darkling which accompanies you throughout the game (and makes up for Jackie's humour) instead of the multiple swarm from the first game but honestly I've never been the tactician type. A secondary campaign, Vendettas, makes up for gameplay. Being almost as long as the main storyline, this campaign is filled to the brink with arena-type encounters and boss fights. To be noticed, though, is that none of the bosses seemed too challenging to the point of being unfair. In fact some might consider them too easy. I played on the "Mobster" (Normal) difficulty.The four new characters we get introduced to are fitting to the overall universe but I consider them bland and making Jackie less unique. While they are sharing different personalities from each other we've seen these types of sterotypes before (the Japanese Katana guy, the Gung-ho lady, the Voodoo guy - probably the most unique out of all, the drunk Irish guy).Ignoring this there is also a list of several "Hitlist" missions which mainly just spans the same areas you've visited throughout the campaign, only refitted for different objectives and the kind. It's not like 90% of the campaign consisted of mostly clearing out areas of enemies and fighting boss battles from time to time. These are quickly done and should be finished in about 2 hours.Among all that, the game features a "New Game+" mode which allows you to replay missions independently in order to pick up remaining achievements and relics. The Relics were something I actively sought and were fun to collect. Don't get yourself fooled, though, because some of them are somewhat hard to find. Should I note that there are 2 possible endings?The Darkness II is a good game, and boy does it give justice to the series. Same thing but kept fresh. A price of 30$ is understandable at the time, but unless you're dying to play this I suggest you wait for sales.

												I absolutely love this game! From the visual graphic novel style graphics, the gun and tentacle toting gameplay, the stereotyped mob characters, and to the delightful voice acting, this game has provided me with many hours of entertainment. The story is just deep enough to keep you interested, the characters are just deep enough for you to actually like them, and the environments are nicely varied but the gameplay is its strong point with its unique "Quad-Wielding" combat. The Single-Player Campaign may seem a bit short for some but the Co-op Campaign is almost just as fun and it sort of makes up for it as some of the missions intertwine/connect with the Single-Player Campaign story. 												Ok, so I was expecting a regular FPS.But, I was wrong, Darkness II was a bit of a shocker to me, it was really good, kinda short maybe, but fun and had a solid story.Story: (Trying not to make spoilers)The game is based on a comic series called, yep, you guessed it, The Darkness.You play as Jackie Estacado, a mafia boss that possess the forces of darkness. Jackie tries to keep his darkness at bay, but after a rival mafia tries to kill you, you have no option but to start a war and unleash the darkness within you upon your enemies.But, when you unleash the darkness, you also cut a deal with it, and there's a price to pay at the end...Graphics:The game graphics reminded me Borderlands but more realistic, and i like it :) kinda gives you the feel of a comics (which it is based on a comic series)Gameplay:The game is FPS and RPG of some sort, where you gain XP from kills and level your skills, but apart from the guns and black magic you also have 2 tenticals that devours, kill, cutting off heads and ripping the limbs of people (Tons of blood and gore)When you are not cutting and killing, you also play as your little lackey, which is more stealthy than just killing everybody.Also, there are some levels that are purely for the story, they are short but very fun and delivers the awesome story to you, I loved those parts!Conclusion:This game kinda surprised me, I loved the story, the cut-scenes are great, the gameplay is fun, the graphics are very nice and feel you get is very good.and even though it's short (took me about 6 hours to finish the game on Hard, but you can play it and make different decisions), it's really good!Play it!***There's also multiplayer but I didn't play it honestly, for no reason really***

YouTube™ Video: The Darkness [Music] - Massacre On The Lighthouse 

			Views: 135,969		

			http://www.2kgames.com/thedarkness/		

	The Darkness II is a first person shooter with some strong story elements.  It also offers some multiplayer/co-op options, where you havethe availability to play a different campaign than the one you play solo,which is nice.  	The story is loosely based on The Darkness comic series, and takes place two years after the first game.  You play as Jackie Estacado, the don of a crime family that posesses a supernatural power called The Darkness.With this power, you have extra arms, or tentacles, that can pick up enemies, throw objects, and  other options that are added as you progress through thegame. The story is very narrational based and entertaining, and connects onan emotional level to the player.  	There are a variety of weapons that are offered;  the recoil on eventhe most basic weapons are very well done, as well as the aim and reload time.They don't ever feel like they are too weak.  The combat is also done well,giving a sense of urgency as you progress through, and a fluidity during battles.   	The darkness has powers and abilities that you can unlock and upgradeas you progress through the game.  There is a decent variety in the selectionof abilities, and they do run on a cool down time.  I felt that the combatwas fair, and rewarded me appropriately as I went through levels.  	As for level design, the game is very linear, but it does compensate for that with a strong fluidity of the combat.  As you progress throughthe levels, the story as well as the fluidity of combat helps break up thelinear feel of it.  The game is consistant in its' aesthetic and atmosphere,and everything flowed very well.  	 There were a few minor issues, which I detail in my video review, butoverall this is a good game with well done combat and a compelling story.  Thelevel design is basic, but I never felt my time was wasted, and I can easilyrecommend this game.This is a summary of what I talk about in the video, I am a YT'er not a BloggerThanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												I’m Jackie Estacado and I am the host for the Darkness. It’s a rough life fighting it from taking me over completely but man does it have some sweet powers. There has been some bad consequences though like losing the love of my life Jenny. I’m dealing with that and now some brotherhood wants to take the Darkness from me. Not going to happen on my watch.In the Darkness II you are still suffering from the loss of Jenny from the first game. You have held the Darkness at bay for a while but now some group called the Brotherhood wants to take it from you using a device called the siphon which will suck the Darkness out of you. Well you aren’t going to let this happen because it’s just bad news for everyone.There are a variety of ways to play through the levels fighting the Brotherhood. You can quad-wield now unlike the first game which gives you options like rip a car door off and use it as a shield while still being able to carry two guns and whip people with you other Darkness tentacle. Special executions can be done by grabbing an enemy with the tentacles, while he is stunned, and rip them apart for more health or ammo. You can also upgrade your powers via a skill tree wheel to add more possibilities like an execution that makes a shield from the enemy or had a Darkness swarm which stuns enemies for a short time. Unlike the first game you only have one Darkling to help you but he has more of a personality than before. He adds a little humor to everything which lightens the dark mood a bit. Guns are your standard fair ranging from pistols, smgs, assault rifles, and shotguns. You can upgrade you guns to buy adding bigger clips, faster reloads, and shooting Darkness essence through them.The game does look good most of the time with its comic book pastel art style. Environments seemed to be pretty bland though and felt like I was just going through a reskinned map each level. Enemies were also basic with pretty much the same five skins all the time. Story wise I wasn’t too impressed and sometimes felt like I was just pushing forward to finish the game so it was no longer in my backlog. I just felt like it was just missing something the whole time. The endings, there are two choices, were both mediocre and not fulfilling. Expected a bigger finish than it was. You can replay it again in new game+ which lets you keep all your unlocked powers. I just didn’t feel the pull to do it though.Darkness II also has a co-op campaign mode called Vendetta you can play with up to four players. It’s basically a side story to the campaign where you can control your choice of four different characters who have their own special Darkness powers. All these characters also have skills you can upgrade to make them more powerful. There is another mode you can pick through Vendetta called The Hit List which is basically shorter missions using the Vendetta campaign levels. Both these modes are cool to play with some friends but doesn’t really add much to the game.Overall if you’re a fan of the comic and enjoyed the first Darkness then you’ll want to check this one out. It could have been much more without the co-op stuff and just focused on the single player portion of the game but it is still a decent game to play.Bear Rating 7.0/10

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												Let me sum up The Darkness (1) for you(Just in case you didn't play the first one): The player takes the role of Jackie Estacado (voiced by Kirk Acevedo), with the story presented as a future-narrative on the present events observed by the player. On the eve of his 21st birthday, Jackie is targeted for assassination by "Uncle" Paulie Franchetti (voiced by Dwight Schultz), a New York Mafia boss, following a failed task to retrieve money for the latter. While hiding in a cemetery bathroom, the Darkness (voiced by Mike Patton), an ancient demonic force that has inhabited his family for several generations, awakens within Jackie and slaughters the remaining mobsters, with the benefit of Jackie becoming the possessor of seemingly unholy demonic abilities that work only in the dark. Using these powers, Jackie proceeds to destroy Paulie's business by killing his biggest drug peddler, Dutch Oven Harry (voiced by Richard Leighton), and burning down the slaughterhouse where he stores his money. In retribution, Paulie and his main enforcer, Captain Eddie Shrote (voiced by Jim Mathers) of the New York City Police Department, kidnap Jackie's girlfriend Jenny Romano (voiced by Lauren Ambrose). They take her to the orphanage where Jackie and Jenny grew up and murder her in front of a powerless Jackie, who is unable to save Jenny due to the Darkness deliberately restraining him.Jackie then commits suicide out of sheer emotional stress, finding himself in the Otherworld, the realm of the Darkness, which is home to patchwork undead beings in World War I outfits fighting each other and physical manifestations of the Four Horsemen. He meets his great-great-grandfather Anthony Estacado (voiced by Kirk Baltz), who reveals that it was he that brought the Darkness into the family and tells Jackie how to free himself of the Darkness by invading the castle in the Otherworld and facing the Darkness there. Jackie is interrupted in his journey through the Otherworld and brought back to the living.Once he recovers, Jackie determines that he must dispose of Captain Shrote before he can face Paulie. After failing to kill Shrote at his apartment, Jackie steals a briefcase containing illicit goods in Shrote's ownership from a Turkish bath that is used as a front by his corrupt police officers. Jackie rigs the briefcase with an explosive and sets up a meeting with Shrote at Trinity Church. Jackie heads to the meeting to kill Shrote, but he is instead captured by his men following a shootout. After overhearing about a shipment of drugs that a Chicago mob is entrusting to Paulie to handle from one of Shrote's officers, Jackie triggers the explosive, killing Shrote and his men along with himself. Jackie re-awakes in the Otherworld and lays siege to the Darkness's castle with Anthony's help. Anthony is mortally wounded in the attack, but before he can tell Jackie the last steps needed to free himself from the Darkness, the spirit pulls him away.Jackie faces the Darkness and surprises it by willingly being taken by the Darkness's power, allowing him to fully control the spirit back in the real world. However, the Darkness tells him that while he has control now, each time Jackie takes a life, he will become more consumed by the Darkness. He lays an assault on the drug shipment, causing Paulie to flee to the safety of a lighthouse mansion for fear of retribution from the Chicago mob. Jackie takes advantage of a solar eclipse to raid the mansion and finally kill Paulie. The Darkness revels in Jackie's murderous spree, and fully envelops Jackie.In the epilogue, Jackie finds himself in a dream, lying on a park bench in Jenny's arms. Jenny explains that they are only allowed a few minutes to be together one last time to say goodbye. Jackie tries to ask how, but Jenny just quiets him, allowing them to enjoy the last moments together before Jackie wakes back up with the screen fading to black.Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Darkness_(video_game)The Darkness 2 on the other hand takes you into the New life of Jackie Estacado.

												A visceral and explosive shooter that gives you a ton and a half of tools to play with in its entirely too short duration.Pros:+ Story is original and captivating for the most part. Some characters, including the protagonist, are interesting and well voice-acted.+ Technical graphics are a bit dated, but artistically, they're pretty unique and relishable. Some real cool set-pieces and enviornments.+ Your options are immense. Decent array of guns, "Darkness" demons allow for varried melee, special attacks, executions, and thrown projectiles.+ Neat skill system that lets you tailor your play-style to execution, melee, special attacks, guns, or a bit of all four.+ Weapons and Darkness weapons have brutal impact. Did I mention quad-wielding?+ Enemy variety forces you to change tactics.Cons:- "Avoid/destroy enviornmental lights, they hurt you" gets old and dissorienting really quickly. Your screen is often blurred trying to find a light to shoot, disabiling your darkness powers and letting enemies tear you apart while it happens.- The mafia tone to the story is horridly stereotypical. Good thing it shifts to the supernatural pretty quickly. - Some enemies are annoying or blatantly unfair. Flashbang throwers, whip-carriers that steal your guns, shield carriers.- Some actions can conflict due to the same button being used for them. The E key eats enemy's hearts to replishing your HP, but also picks up guns. I've swapped plenty of guns on accident and died because I didn't get my health pickup.- Too short. Main campaign took me 5 hours on second hardest difficulty.- "Vendetta" missions do not use Jackie. They're co-op missions with a new crew of marauders, but you'll miss a lot of Jackie's abilities.^ Cons are nit-picky for the most part, but some really tear you out from the action too much. This game is worth buying if just for the main campaign alone, but know how short it is. Too unique and too fun to dismiss.
