												It's strange how sometimes you can like a game the first 10 minutes, see yourself hate it thoroughly after playing 30 minutes, almost giving the entire game up, and in the end love it so much it's end up on your favorites games list... The Darkness II is NOT that type of game. The first game however, is definitely that type of game. After a slow start and what seems to be a big nuisance -the maze of connected levels through the New York subway- it starts to grow on you, it feels like you are right there with Jackie Estacado, a betrayed hitman for the mafia, helping him travel from the one rotten place to the next forsaken hell (literally) all the while thinking about your sins and the losses you had to suffer. And all of this because a evil force is helping you fulfill your vengeance but by every heart taken from the bodies of fallen enemies it takes you one step closer to the darkness and its goal to ultimately take complete control of your mind, will and body. There develops and plays out a story that’s gruesome and poetic at times, you will remember it, it will haunt you. Let's spill the beans right now for those not interested in reading a lengthy piece. It's not easy to follow up Starbreeze's gem but Digital Extremes (DE) did a good job for a sequel. While it does not satisfy as much and does not answer all the burning questions you have after playing the first one (how did Jackie return?) they at least took over most important aspects and characters from the first one that made it memorable and continue on those. That also has it's flip side, when a sequel focuses on the most memorable aspects it forgets the subtle details that made the first great. The new york subway as a game hub is no more and therefore the unique pacing of the first game is also gone. This game capitalizes on the action and creates a big deja vu of the first story and works towards a way too obvious end. As such you will feel for the characters only because you went on the dark journey with them in the first, not from what you experience in the Darkness II.But the action, that it does good. While I personally enjoyed the more realistic style of the first, the cell shaded look of the second game will not throw you off that much. It's still gory and it still has many themes that could be deemed controversial for a game and I guess because the game did not became that much of a hit that these moments have gone unnoticed. The gun game play is improved and you get more darkness powers to play with (damn you stupid skill trees, choices, choices...). DE was also smart enough to leave out some overpowered skills out of the game or downgrade them a little bit to make the playing field more fair. The enemies are also much aware of the Darkness and it's powers and flaws and are much tougher then the unknowing mobsters from the first game. Flash grenades and portable lights will certainly give you a fight to find a spot of darkness and to unleash your dark powers. In the end I enjoyed the darkness II very much for its game play and rehearses of the first games story. However, I play a game for it's story and hoped for a different direction, a story arc the same as the first is a bit of a let down. If you have your heart set on playing this then play the first game first and then decide if you want to play the Darkness II. If you do you will at least play this game with more passion for the characters and you will already have developed a love/hate relationship with one of the coolest voices featured in a game and the gravely twisted mind that is the Darkness.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2013
												The Darkness II is a short (single player campaign is about 5-6 hours) and gory but a rather fun game. The story is somewhat depressing but it also sets the mood for it. You're meant to feel Jackie's rage - and he will rage, a lot. The plot has some rather interesting twists, which made it enjoyable. The game is cartoon-styled, much like Borderlands and The Walking Dead. I really like the way the game looks and it makes the gory details seem less.. gross.  The gameplay is really fun, you earn points on being creative that you can spend on upgrading your abilities, in the end you might feel like you're almost invincible. Since the Darkness is vulnerable in the light you have to stay out of it, which can be a challenge sometimes. I love the game play, the demon arms are a fun addition and saves the game from becoming just a generic shooter. You also have a companion that you can throw around, he deserves it for calling you "Monkey"!There are some extra side-missions with co-op and a new game+ mode as well that might earn the game a bit more replay value. Since it's a short game you should keep in mind if you are considering to buy it.

												Fret not if you've never played the original Darkness. While many allusions are made its way, The Darkness II has you covered with a concise recap.The first Darkness was a mess of a game, marred with terrible voice acting, animations, controls, gameplay, and numerous other bugs. The Darkness II, a product by another team of developers, is fortunately an exemplary sequel, fixing nearly every flaw and adding major improvements in ways unimaginable.Graphically, The Darkness II's cel shading is simply beautiful, fitting right in with its comic book counterpart. The animations are smooth and the over-the-top violence is a blast to watch. Controls, especially during combat, flow extremely well, even in the face of the overwhelming number abilities available.While the single player campaign isn't too lengthy, the game doubles its duration with the inclusion of a cooperative mode offering 18 missions and 4 new, unique characters. There's simply a lot of content to be found.Grade: B

Posted: August 24, 2014
												It's a fun game, for the six or so hours that the campaign lasts. And I played it on hard.You play as a generic mafioso who, after the tutorial, reveals that he's the host for The Darkness, a malevolent entity which gleefully kills people in a bunch of horrifically fun ways. About halfway through the plot your character is killed and is then resurrected by The Darkness, which makes you realize that dying during gameplay really shouldn't be that big a deal if your inner demon can just bring you back to life following the subtle plot twist of getting shotgunned in the face.I have some minor gripes with the controls; you'll want to remap them or else your attempts to aim, shoot, and flail around with your demon arms basically results in you stumbling and haphazardly firing your guns into the ceiling and walls like a drunken redneck.There is a variety of enemies to encounter who make the combat a lot of fun and interesting.The plot and it's overall theme of sanity and evil versus absolute evil were quite enjoyable, and I liked that the game had at least two different endings.I haven't played the 'vendetta' content yet, but considering the "Main Story" lasted less than six hours I feel justified reviewing the game without playing all of its content.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												With it's story depending highly on your experience of Starbreeze's console exclusive release of 2007, it is some wonder that this sequel to Darkness was made available for PC or, heck, even at all when you consider how the first game even ended. Yet with the stark differences in art-style and ultimately approach to the structure itself  in The Darkness 2, Digital Extremes also wisely fixed the cumbersome combat of the original Darkness with much better shooting mechanics and much better implementation of the titular demon itself during fights. Additionally, the co-op heavy Vendettas game mode is a nice surprise and a lot of fun both online and off. Performance is neither an issue here or there with this one, The Darkness II can be maxed out smoothly on modest DX10 video cards and budget Dual core CPUs although it doesn't quite have proper full-frame support, squashing the picture similar to Digital Extreme's previous work on Homefront. Otherwise, aside from the occassional cheap enemy chokepoint, you're more than likely to enjoy what you get out of The Darkness II, especially if it is less than £5.

												The Darkness 2 has passable gameplay with about 10 weapons, half of them being what I would consider upgrades of a lower tier. It has a low replay value with not much to do after beating the Story and Vendetta/Hit List Missions (about 9-10 hours altogether). The best thing it has going for it and why I recommend the game is the single player Campaign portion of the game.There is very little stalling in the plot. The game starts with the reveal of a new enemy and has about 3 objectives that are logical to progressing before starting the arc with the big bad guy. To me that is very efficient at getting to the point. I was nervous every time a sentimental moment happened, worried if the game would do a cheap jumpscare. It compelled me to care about what was going on and that is a rare feeling for me to have with dramatic stories like this.Each time you can go back to your base, the other characters have different things to tell you that aren't always related to what you are doing, such as the story told about eddie when Jackie and Vincent are catching up. If you are into playing a game and exploring the subtle changes, you will be rewarded for your time. The plot constantly attempts to mess with your judgement of the situation and makes every chance for a choice an uneased gut check.Check the game out when you have the opportunity to pay attention to the dialogue and really grasp the story. It was inspired by a comic book series and plays like reading an interactive graphic novel.

Posted: August 24, 2014
												It's a fun game, for the six or so hours that the campaign lasts. And I played it on hard.You play as a generic mafioso who, after the tutorial, reveals that he's the host for The Darkness, a malevolent entity which gleefully kills people in a bunch of horrifically fun ways. About halfway through the plot your character is killed and is then resurrected by The Darkness, which makes you realize that dying during gameplay really shouldn't be that big a deal if your inner demon can just bring you back to life following the subtle plot twist of getting shotgunned in the face.I have some minor gripes with the controls; you'll want to remap them or else your attempts to aim, shoot, and flail around with your demon arms basically results in you stumbling and haphazardly firing your guns into the ceiling and walls like a drunken redneck.There is a variety of enemies to encounter who make the combat a lot of fun and interesting.The plot and it's overall theme of sanity and evil versus absolute evil were quite enjoyable, and I liked that the game had at least two different endings.I haven't played the 'vendetta' content yet, but considering the "Main Story" lasted less than six hours I feel justified reviewing the game without playing all of its content.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2012
												Fret not if you've never played the original Darkness. While many allusions are made its way, The Darkness II has you covered with a concise recap.The first Darkness was a mess of a game, marred with terrible voice acting, animations, controls, gameplay, and numerous other bugs. The Darkness II, a product by another team of developers, is fortunately an exemplary sequel, fixing nearly every flaw and adding major improvements in ways unimaginable.Graphically, The Darkness II's cel shading is simply beautiful, fitting right in with its comic book counterpart. The animations are smooth and the over-the-top violence is a blast to watch. Controls, especially during combat, flow extremely well, even in the face of the overwhelming number abilities available.While the single player campaign isn't too lengthy, the game doubles its duration with the inclusion of a cooperative mode offering 18 missions and 4 new, unique characters. There's simply a lot of content to be found.Grade: B

content:
Posted: August 13, 2013
												With it's story depending highly on your experience of Starbreeze's console exclusive release of 2007, it is some wonder that this sequel to Darkness was made available for PC or, heck, even at all when you consider how the first game even ended. Yet with the stark differences in art-style and ultimately approach to the structure itself  in The Darkness 2, Digital Extremes also wisely fixed the cumbersome combat of the original Darkness with much better shooting mechanics and much better implementation of the titular demon itself during fights. Additionally, the co-op heavy Vendettas game mode is a nice surprise and a lot of fun both online and off. Performance is neither an issue here or there with this one, The Darkness II can be maxed out smoothly on modest DX10 video cards and budget Dual core CPUs although it doesn't quite have proper full-frame support, squashing the picture similar to Digital Extreme's previous work on Homefront. Otherwise, aside from the occassional cheap enemy chokepoint, you're more than likely to enjoy what you get out of The Darkness II, especially if it is less than £5.

												This game is one of those great weekend games that you can pick up and beat In just a couple of days,The combat is fast and fun and very violent, all the way from the starting credits to the final battle (depending on what you choose, but no spoilers).All the action of the game is supplemented by short trips to your home base, were you can talk to other characters in the game for tid bits of lore and comments on your current objectives, there are also a few little mini games you can play that will help you get in some target practice...... ill just call it that lol.The game also features simple rpg mechanic that gives you the chance to upgrade skills depeneding on your play style, the game rewards you for killing in varied and unique was and its great fun to try out all the new tactics that you will unlock as you progress further along in a skill branch.Only CON I can say with this game is the length, if you power your way through as I did on a second playthrough with some skills under your belt you can EZLY beat the game in about 4 hours, however if you take the time to test out new skills (BLACK HOLE FTW!!!), take time to talk to all the characters in the game, which I suggest you do on first run, the game can EZLY last for a good 8 hours.I would say the overall experience is worth the asking price, but if you see it on sale, pick it up with out a doubt.7/10, would give it a 8/10 if the game was just a bit longer.

content:
Posted: January 22
												I pick this up after I read an article that placed it in the best 50 FPS ever made. And DAMN if they weren't right. The first thing I noticed upon starting the game is that I was missing a LOT of backstory. I managed to piece most of it together before the end, but I'm still not clear on some things. So, you're Jackie Estacado, some sort of Mafia Don. You're well-loved by the people in your organization, even they're very much aware that you've made some sort of deal with a demonic entity that causes you to sprout eel-like growths from your back that you can cut people in half with (Which I find weird, considering that most popular media portrays most of the Italian mob as at least moderately Catholic, but whatever).The game is starting to show it's age, but when it came out, it would have been looking pretty good. It's still an attractive game, and the various little visual effects are pretty sweet for when it came out. The art style is very dark, which fits the story to a "T." The various NPCs you interact with are all interesting, if 2-dimensional. Maybe if I'd played the first one, I'd be more invested in them. The learning curve is pretty much ideal. The tutorial is a mite frustrating, considering that you don't have any agency over what you can do when, but that's just me. Otherwise, the skills take long enough to grab that you become practiced at using each of them before you grab a new one. The enemy's AI is pretty damn solid, I gotta say. Good use of cover, suppressing fire, and even flanking actions. It surprised me quite a few times. The gameplay is where this game REALLY shines. Right in the first 10 minutes of the game, you're using your two tentacle beasts to wreak havoc and MAN it's fun. The right tentacle beast looks like it's kinda more fragile, and has massive friggin' fangs. Accordingly, this is the one you use to slash people up and whip 'em to death. This simple tentacle whip remains a valid strategy right up until the very last fight. The left tentacle is more muscle-y, and is definitely my favorite of the two. With it, you can grab various bits of scenery and chuck 'em around at high speed, with a generous auto-target. And not just blunt trauma. You can cut blokes in half with car doors and fans, impale them with bits of pipe, or even bludgeon them with bits and pieces of their dead buddies. Loads of fun. The game affords you a generous armament, but you really don't want to use them for kills, as a bullet kill nets you a lousy 10 essence.     I haven't even gotten to the skill tree yet! Each kill you get and action you take gives you "essence" which basically functions as xp. 20 essence for impaling a guy, 30 for ripping him in half lengthwise, 30 for ripping out his intestines through his♥♥♥♥♥♥ etc. The fights are frantic enough, and your body count high enough, that you can amass massive amounts of essence relatively quickly.  The skills themselves are high in cost, especially the top-tier ones, but some of them are absolutely absurd. I picked up one near the end that let me harvest miniature black holes from dead bodies and throw them. How awesome is that?The music was good. No complaints there. There were some bits in cutscenes that gave me the friggin' heebie-jeebies, all because of the music. So, all told, I'd definitely recommend this. Even if you're not super invested in the plot, it's fun as hell.My Scores:Graphics: 8/10Learning Curve: 10/10AI: 10/10Gameplay: 10/10Music: 9/10Overall: 47/50

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												If you enjoy quite literally ripping into your foes then you'll love this game.  The Darkness' powers are well designed, allowing you to easily use them while using your firearms rather than requiring you to switching back and forth.  The basics of gameplay are -- and remain -- simple, giving you tougher, better protected and more numerous obstacles rather than expecting you to memorize dozens of specific-use powers.  Even better, the cooldowns on major abilities are reasonable and there's no annoying MP/SP systems.  No "saving it for when I REALLY need it" here.  Go wild and give your enemies a new, bettter reason to fear the dark (if only for the last few seconds of their life).  Hell, you can feasibly go through the whole game without ever using the guns to fight.  I know I certainly had much more fun ripping and slashing and impaling and decapitating everyone in sight with every object in sight than traditional "shoot, run forward, shoot" could have delivered.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												(Single player only review)Based on a comic book I never read, The Darkness II puts you as Jackie, a mafioso crime boss who is a host for a supernatural evil entity called "The Darkness". The Darkness grants you superpowers, the most obvious being two long snake-like demon arms, which among other things act as a powerful melee weapon. The downside is that The Darkness is deceiving and manipulative and will slowly consume it's host the more it is let loose. The theme and atmosphere is best described as a mix of a gangster movie with a solid dose of horror and splatter. Things get very brutal and gory, but the slightly cell-shaded graphics gives it a comic book look, which takes the edge of it all. Some of the characters you come across have a ton of personality, perfectly conveyed by top-notch voice acting  and brilliant over-the-top motion-captured gestures/body language.The sound and graphics are very good, but the sub par level of geometry detail shows it's console heritage and never pushes the 3d-engine hard enough to drop a single frame on my Geforce 780 with everything maxed.The story itself (spoiler alert) has two main plot lines: Someone is after you, because they want The Darkness, and you are haunted by recurring nightmares/hallucinations about your dead love which leads you to believe that perhaps she is still somehow to be saved.Normally I get easily bored with long winded mediocre story telling in video games, but I found the story, albeit perhaps trivial in nature, to be thoroughly entertaining, in part due to the excellent delivery.The core gameplay is fairly standard, linear, but very solid FPS in a generally confined level design. It does however feature 4 skill trees which will definitely help skew the gameplay in the direction you prefer:-Gun upgrades (clip sizes and permanent damage bonuses)-Demon arm execution bonuses-Demon arm melee upgrades (they can also grab and throw objects and enemies)-Upgrades to Swarm (a plague-like insect swarm that will stun and hurt your enemies) and Gun Channeling (a short period where you get various gun related boosts)You have 4 gun slots, and you can dual-wield.You purchase new skills by spending "Essence", which is earned mainly by killing enemies, preferably by having you demon arms executing them in a horrific ways, and finding artifacts. Having your demon arms eat the hearts of the corpses will also give you some essence in addition to a health boost. Health regenerates up to the nearest 25% level when you haven't been hurt in a while.The A.I. was decent, and I didn't encounter any bugs worth mentioning.Other mentionable features:- Light. The Darkness doesn't like the light, and exposure to it means the demon arms will retract and you lose all your super powers until you are in the dark again. Light will also visually blind you by distorting the display thus handicapping your aim. Later on in the campaign you'll encounter foes with powerful flashlights and light grenades. As I generally dislike enemy attacks that handicaps/restricts you I found this aspect of the gameplay a little too annoying at times.So make sure to find and eliminate all destructable light sources in an area before you engage your enemies.- A sidekick midget demon with a cockney accent. You'll get to control him a couple of times during the campaign, which are stealthy missions. In his standard form he does little but occasionally distract some of your foes leaving them essentially stunned and open for your attack. But there's a talent in the skill tree that'll enable him to actually kill foes.Other than that he does little but urinate and fart on the corpses you produce, and wisely telling you to avoid the light while constantly referring to you as "monkey" (yup, it gets annoying). Fortunately he doesn't like the light either, so you can always throw him into the spotlight for some relief.Bottom line - 6 hours of linear, stylish, satisfying FPS action with a brilliantly delivered horrific story and theme. 80%

Posted: March 9, 2014
												Aren't these the guys who developed Unreal and Unreal Tournament? I know of no other Digital Extremes. Beside them you also have 2K so you really have everything you need to make a really good game.I never played the first one as it was never released on PC. But from what I understand the story takes place a couple of years after the events of its predecessor. You play the don of an infamous crime family who is attacked at the beginning of the story. One of the rival gangs almost eliminates Jackie, our protagonist, who eventually gives in to the Darkness which saves his life.And this is where the game gets interesting: Jackie has two tentacles protruding from his body and you can use them to crush, dismember or simply slice up your enemies. Oh, and of course you have your good old pistols, machine guns and shotguns to annihilate all the bad guys approaching you. Jackie did not want the Darkness to return - under the circumstances, however, he needs to rely on them and throughout the game you need to find out who and why attacked you in the restaurant.With the tentacles you can also pick up objects - e.g. the door of a vehicle - and throw them at your enemies. And as you can do some dual wielding with the firearms you can practically say you are doing quad wielding with the two tendrils. How cooler can a game be, am I right? With the killings you can collect what the game calls essence; a substance that eventually lets you purchase new powers or the upgraded version of the ones you already have. It should also be note that as the title refers to it darkness is also Jackie's ally - if you are in an illuminated area the tentacles immediately retract.Darkness II is a fast-paced action horror game that utilises a cel-shading technique to give the game a comic book influenced visual style. Multiplayer is limited to cooperative gameplay that does not really add anything to the story but lets you enjoy quad wielding with your friends.I highly recommend it - for 30 EUR it's a bit too much at the moment but you should definitely pick this one up if discounted.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												This review is written after one playthrough of the main game, and one playthrough of the co-op campaign (allthough I did it by my lonesome). Boht on mobster (medium) difficulty)The story is my opinion very well written and exciting, allthough linear and short. The gameplay was fast paced and exciting. I was worried the two extra "arms" would be hard to use, but using a gamepad it quickly started feeling natural, and the controls all in all worked very well, and were easy to learn. The key to victory in combat is combining firearms and darkness powers (some learned through the skilltree), and it's easy to learn - and honestly not particularly hard to master either. That's not to say it's a particularly easy game though, even though your darkness powers allows you to tear through some parts of the game.The co-op campaign has a story that runs next to the story of the main campaign, focusing on 4 mercenaries hired by the "protagonist", Jackie Estacado, to shoot people, fetch stuff, shoot people, rescue hostages and occasionally shoot people. Each of the 4 mercs have access to parts of the Darkness' powers (like regeneration, super helpsome), and they each have an unique weapon as well as an unique skilltree. The co-op campaign is even shorter than the main game, the map-design isn't as exciting, but designed for bigger battles. I played through it alone, so I don't know how well it works with more players,  but I found it entertaining enough, even though the difficulty varied wildly, allthough I think that may have been because I was alone.The graphics are pleasing, and made in a comic-y style, which also makes the constant gore a little less realistic, making the game feel a bit less graphic than I had expected. The animation is for the most parts good, though some characters feel a bit stiff. The quality of the voice work varies a bit, but is for the most parts good - the screams of terror from the enemies seem convincing and such.All in all I think this is a good game with fair graphics, it is however quite short. The current price, 30 euro, is a bit more than I feel it's worth. Catch it on sale some time, and tear up some gangsters and♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												(Single player only review)Based on a comic book I never read, The Darkness II puts you as Jackie, a mafioso crime boss who is a host for a supernatural evil entity called "The Darkness". The Darkness grants you superpowers, the most obvious being two long snake-like demon arms, which among other things act as a powerful melee weapon. The downside is that The Darkness is deceiving and manipulative and will slowly consume it's host the more it is let loose. The theme and atmosphere is best described as a mix of a gangster movie with a solid dose of horror and splatter. Things get very brutal and gory, but the slightly cell-shaded graphics gives it a comic book look, which takes the edge of it all. Some of the characters you come across have a ton of personality, perfectly conveyed by top-notch voice acting  and brilliant over-the-top motion-captured gestures/body language.The sound and graphics are very good, but the sub par level of geometry detail shows it's console heritage and never pushes the 3d-engine hard enough to drop a single frame on my Geforce 780 with everything maxed.The story itself (spoiler alert) has two main plot lines: Someone is after you, because they want The Darkness, and you are haunted by recurring nightmares/hallucinations about your dead love which leads you to believe that perhaps she is still somehow to be saved.Normally I get easily bored with long winded mediocre story telling in video games, but I found the story, albeit perhaps trivial in nature, to be thoroughly entertaining, in part due to the excellent delivery.The core gameplay is fairly standard, linear, but very solid FPS in a generally confined level design. It does however feature 4 skill trees which will definitely help skew the gameplay in the direction you prefer:-Gun upgrades (clip sizes and permanent damage bonuses)-Demon arm execution bonuses-Demon arm melee upgrades (they can also grab and throw objects and enemies)-Upgrades to Swarm (a plague-like insect swarm that will stun and hurt your enemies) and Gun Channeling (a short period where you get various gun related boosts)You have 4 gun slots, and you can dual-wield.You purchase new skills by spending "Essence", which is earned mainly by killing enemies, preferably by having you demon arms executing them in a horrific ways, and finding artifacts. Having your demon arms eat the hearts of the corpses will also give you some essence in addition to a health boost. Health regenerates up to the nearest 25% level when you haven't been hurt in a while.The A.I. was decent, and I didn't encounter any bugs worth mentioning.Other mentionable features:- Light. The Darkness doesn't like the light, and exposure to it means the demon arms will retract and you lose all your super powers until you are in the dark again. Light will also visually blind you by distorting the display thus handicapping your aim. Later on in the campaign you'll encounter foes with powerful flashlights and light grenades. As I generally dislike enemy attacks that handicaps/restricts you I found this aspect of the gameplay a little too annoying at times.So make sure to find and eliminate all destructable light sources in an area before you engage your enemies.- A sidekick midget demon with a cockney accent. You'll get to control him a couple of times during the campaign, which are stealthy missions. In his standard form he does little but occasionally distract some of your foes leaving them essentially stunned and open for your attack. But there's a talent in the skill tree that'll enable him to actually kill foes.Other than that he does little but urinate and fart on the corpses you produce, and wisely telling you to avoid the light while constantly referring to you as "monkey" (yup, it gets annoying). Fortunately he doesn't like the light either, so you can always throw him into the spotlight for some relief.Bottom line - 6 hours of linear, stylish, satisfying FPS action with a brilliantly delivered horrific story and theme. 80%

content:
Posted: January 15, 2013
												The Darkness is a pretty standard shooter with a little superpowers thrown in for good measure. The single-player is fairly well balanced if a little on the easy side even on the harder difficulties. The story is surprisingly decent and grey and gritty enough that you won't feel like vomiting too often.The premise is simple enough. There is this thing, a being of pure evil, called The Darkness. It can't interact directly with our world so it needs to attach itself to a human being giving that individual incredible powers as well as slowly corrupting that person. You play as Jackie who's family is tied to the Darkness is some way that was probably explained in the detail in the first game, you have the Darkness inside you but somehow managed to contain it, until a weird old guy who knows a little bit of magic himself shows up and tries to kill you and everybody you know. You quickly abandon logic, unleash the Darkness and go on a killing spree.The game plays out as a standard shooter most of the time with a few added elements, as the wielder of the Darkness you have two big snake like creatures growing out your body that can be used to hit things, grab things and eat things. You are also handicapped by being vulnerable to light. While a shooter with superpowers isn't exactly a new thing it plays fairly well, the combat is fluid as are the transitions between shooting at people and slashing them with your pet snakes.The storyline is, much to my surprise, fairly well written and while not given you much choice it does ask a number of questions about morality and reality. The ending in particular will be a surprise to most players. In addition there is a decent amount of lore and back story available to those that seek it.It all has one major flaw however, it's length. Even playing the game to 100% completion, which requires at least two playthroughs of the main campaign as well as playing through a number of multi-player mini-campaigns will only take you a little over 10-12 hours and that is quite simply unacceptable for a game that was originally marketed with a full 50$ price tag.The graphic style is generally a bit cartoonish which contrasts heavily with the stark and grim story and gameplay.All in all The Darkness 2 is a decent enough play, and some good fun with a couple of friends. It is however not a game you should ever contemplate buying at full price simply because of it's extremely short lifespan.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												In general a very enjoyable game. Not going to lie, it has a few kinks I hope they fix for Darkness III (oh please let it happen), but those are easy to look past considering all the other great parts of the game.Good things:The story about Jenny is fantastic (minor spoiler, yes she's in the game a bit). It really got me sucked into it all because alot of very logical things surfaced when playing, which gave a rather interresting perspective about the game itself.The gore...I mean come on you have to love it. Actually one of the most brutal games I've ever played, but at the same time not the most graphic one. The artstyle makes you enjoy it alot more than get grossed out by it.The artstyle I can't explain why but I really like it. It has a comic noir sense to it and looks really good.The gameplay has a really nice touch to it. Demons and guns, how do you say no to that? Also there's a skilltree you level up depending on how you want to play, so personalized customization for you and your abilities.Finally you can tell that the developers have put alot of time and effort into the game because of all the amazing voiceacting. If you feel like it you can double your gameplay time by talking to everyone possible and not only get alot of info about what's going on and personal opinions which add alot of depth to the story, you can also enjoy a comedic side to this game which I personally was happily surprised to discover.Things that can be improved:First thing that comes to mind is the amount of execution animations. Though horrendous and incredible great to watch, they get quite repetitive once you've played for a while. For the next game I wish they mix it up a bit and expand the ways you can kill people with your demons, because, and be honest to yourself, that is one of the coolest things about this game.Secondly I really enjoyed the story and the campaign and it all had a nice flow all the way through. I just wish for the flow to extend another few hours. I finished the game in about ten hours or so, and I really think a game should be longer than that. Especially since this one doesn't have free roaming and maybe not so much replay value since the story is such a big part of the game.Overall I give this game 8.5/10. Get it and enjoy this very unique FPS where YOU are the nightmare everyone fears ;)

												Darkness II is one of these games that have many advantages as a game but many drawbacks , too.The graphcis are unusually good (cell-shaded), but the music-soundtrack is uninteresting.The single player is awsome , interesting story , good and solid FPS mechanics , and a awesome skilltree(which give you the ability to unlock both passives and active skills and ofcourse improvments to them).After finishing the single player campaign you can start again a NG++ which means you will keep the unlocked skills you already have from the previous campaign , I personally found it pretty awesome and I had a totally different experience from the 1st playthrough.Except from the campaign single player, the game also gives you the opportunity to play some side missions (which are called vendettas), with 4 new characters each one with his own skilltree and abilities , and a  extra small campaignin which is basically the sum up of the vendettas (or the opposite) .Furthemore some vendettas can be completed with multiplayer co-op. The major drawback is that the main campaign will only last for 5 hours tops (it took me 8 hours with a NG++ game) ,and the vendettas will give you 2-3 more hours.If you decide ofcourse to play the extra campaign or the vendettas with all the charactes (I doubt you will :P ), the time will be multiplied.So here comes the critical question : Are you able/willing to give 30 $ for a game it will only last 12-14 hours tops?Yes the story will be great and Yes the powers and abilities of darkness will be unforgetable but will it worth for the so little time it will last....?In my opinion NO ...buy this game like a did at a steam sale (80%=5$) and you will not regret it.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												NOTE: Despite my short playing time, I have in fact completed this game. I also own a copy on Xbox 360, and this is the copy I completed. The Darkness II is a phsycological horror first-person shooter sequel to The Darkness, a console only game released back in 2009. The original game was interesting despite its flaws, and was a highly enjoyable game in terms of story and gameplay. Its sequel, The Darkness II, goes above and beyond to deliver an absolute gem of a gaming experience, and a masterpiece of the art form. You play as Jackie Estacado, the head of a feared crime family, who is the host to an ancient evil known as The Darkness - this evil resides inside Jackie and gives him supernatural powers. Jackie constantly wrestles for control, and The Darkness forced him to stand by and watch as his girlfriend, Jenny, was murdered. Jenny's murder is the driving force of this entire game. Throughout the game, Jackie experiences hallucinations of Jenny, and interacts with her as she if she never died. These moments are the soul of the game; Jackie and Jenny are beautifully acted, and you can genuinely feel the emotion in these scenes. This made the story a compelling and enjoyable one, and I felt personally compellled to stick this game through to the end.In between cutscenes and interaction with Jenny and other NPC's, Jackie will engage in numerous combat situations. This game uses a unique and innovative combat system, in that the player is able to 'quad-wield'; the player is able to dual wield one handed firearms in combination with the demon tendrils produced by The Darkness. These tendrils let you rip, slash, throw, tear and stab your enemies in a variety of highly entertaining ways, but be warned that these kills are extremely gory and not for the faint hearted. In fact, the entire game is extremely dark, and contains very dark subject matter beyond the usual video game. The player also has to avoid street lights and other artificial lights and shoot them out where possible, as you cannot regenerate health or use Darkness abilities whilst in the light.This game is beautiful in every aspect. The game engine employs a distinct comic-book inspired aesthetic like the Borderlands games, and it really helps make the game look and run nice at the higher settings. Substantial effort and polish has gone into the production of this game, and it really shows; character models look and move realistically, and environments are dazzling to look at.In addition to the perfected single player campaign (which I have been careful not to spoil) there is a mini co-op campaign, which allows you to play with 3 friends and use a wide range of guns and abilities to kill enemies. This mode emphasises fun and action, and lacks the depth of the single player campaign. However, it was certainly fun, and I didn't feel like it detracted from the campaign in any way.Overall, The Darkness II is a masterpiece of the gaming industry. A brilliant, well constructed tale of love and loss and eventually redemption, this is a game for the ages. I can't recommend it any more than I already have, which is why this game earns a 10 / 10.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												So I picked this game up for $1 on humblebundle.com along with Duke Nukem: Forever and Spec Ops: The Line. I looked at the screenshots and I thought, eh it's just going to be another ♥♥♥♥♥♥ alien shooter. Boy was I wrong. (Keep in mind I haven't played the first game) So I'll start with the story. Basically you are Jackie Estacado, the leader of a crime family and mob. You start by getting attacked by another crime mob and your 'darkness' is released from within yourself after having kept it in for so long. You then set out to find who put the attackers up to attacking you. All the while having the darkness for show. People called it 'the thing' or sometimes nicknamed him monkey. With him having released the darkness; it comes with side effects. One of the big ones is hallucinations. Seeing things that aren't there. Jackie had the repetitive hallucination of seeing his dead girlfriend: Jennie/Jenny. Whenever he went to some places the darkness would kick in and show Jennie walking around with him. Jackie not wanting to believe she was dead went along with it and every time was baffaled when she dissapeared. Jackie had a sidekick with him. The 'Darkling'. It was a small monkey like creature with a very Cockney accent. It couldn't be touched by light or it'd die. When you had the darkness on show, you couldn't be in the light either or it'd significantly weaken you. As you proceed with the story you find out that the people who put the attackers up to the attack was 'The Brotherhood' ; led by Victor Valente. They wanted you so they could get the darkness from you. There was only two ways they could get The Darkness from you. 1. By Jackie giving it up by choice. 2. By using the ancient relic: The Siphon. Now Jackie didn't want to give the darkness up because he was led to believe that Jennie's soul was trapped within hell and as long as he had the darkness he could save her. However the Brotherhood eventually trapped Jackie and stole the Darkness via the use of the Siphon. You track Victor down and fight him with what little of the darkness is left and what you steal from one of his minions. Once you kill him, you stab yourself with the Siphon and descend down into the depths of hell. Once in hell you run through trying to find Jennie. Once you find her you use your darkness powers to release her from her shackles (I can't think of the word). However he was being decieved all along. It wasn't Jennie he just released: it was  The Angelus  . The Angelus was the keeper of light. Legend has it The Angelus and The Darkness have fought for eternity. Now I did miss out one part of the story because I didn't know where to fit it in but it was that at points throughout the game where the Darkness was healing Jackie; Jackie actually fell into a dream state which was 'the hospital'. Here the darkness tried to convince him that his crime life was all a dream and he is in the hospital to get better. The Darkling manages to prove that it isn't real and helps him along. My Opinions I have to say I was very impressed. The characters were constructed very well. It made you feel like Jackie did. Going through 2 different worlds; you didn't know what was real or not. It was also a great mind twister. Throughtout the story making sense of things was hard. Which is real? Which isn't? That can't be true? Can it? However towards the end of the story everything tied together and everything made perfect sense. I'd like to say a big well done to the developers. I thoroughly enjoyed this game although it was quite short. Scores Graphics: 7/10Gameplay: 8/10Storyline: 8/10Value for money: 6/10Overall: 29/40

Posted: February 1, 2014
												I'll start by saying i really enjoyed the first Darkness game. The story was really well done and the game had an atmoshpere of darkness and despair that really matched it. While this sequel is a decent game it didn't quite live up to it's predecessor for me. First of all the game's cel-shaded looking visuals while not bad looking, just didn't seem to fit with this game. What should be quite a dark game ends up looking cartoony and it just isn't the right fit. It also makes the game feel a bit more arcadey instead of the visceral feel the gameplay of the first game had. The story while interesting didn't reall captivate me as much as in the first game either and Jackie is also less likeable (though you could argue this might be to reflect the effect of the experiences in the first game on him.)The gameplay and combat isn't too bad. There's a bit more variety with combat in this game and your darkling follower can be quite useful and adds a bit of comical relief. There's also more variety with enemies which require different strategies to deal with.Overall all it's a decent game but nowhere near as good as it's predecessor. If you enjoyed the first game i'd say maybe give this one a go if you can pick it up cheap but but be prepared for the fact that it's not as good. If you didn't like the first you probably won't like this either. It's a 6/10 for me.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												The Darkeness II is not perfect. But I think its flaws dont outweigh what I like, so here we are. I would reccomend the game on sale, as it is wont to go because the combat is fast paced and fun. Sometimes theres a little too little ammo, and especially when enemies can disable your darkness powers this makes some areas a bit too hard, but the combat is fun, fast and brutal. The guns are tight, the darkness controls well, and the cell-shaded look is pretty good looking, especially considering this is based off of a comic book, as well as allowing some odd character desgin, like victor. The villians are vile, and normally I would say this is an attempt to make jackie seem like the better guy-and to a large degree thats true, but the game also never really pretends jackies perfect, so its not as obnoxious as it normally is. The story is ok, not great but not awful, and after reading some of the comic book plot summary, the veering away seems like a good choice. Everything is pretty solid, though I think they could have expanded the story and world a bit more and it would've fleshed it out a bit more.  Perhaps they couldve, but this games biggest problem probably had something to do with that-length. The game is just too damn short, and considering I enjoyed that it makes me sad that this was the case. The length is not ok, the FOV needs to be adjustable-this game is best on PC for the number of buttons that you use in combat, and not having a more adjustable FOV is unnacceptable. Also on PC, there are still bugs that don't let you get through certain areas unless you turn on Vsync, which makes the game look blurry if you leave it on by accident. Thats not ok, escpecially in this day and age of patching. The co-op is enjoyable, though the characters are all flat stereotypes, and  I can understand accusations of racism, though  I chalk it up to laziness more than anything. Still its a fun game, and I would highly reccomend it, though it may make you sad when you beat it to realize they may not make another one, considering the silence around it. Fingers crossed they do.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Well, this was an interesting game to play. A fresh air after playing so many crappy indie productions.Pros:- the plot is kind of nice if you know something about Image Comics and the Artifacts series - reading the story of hidden relics and immersing in the whole Darkness backstory is really fun- graphics are well fitting into comic book stylistics- playing with the Darkness tentacles is really fun- the whole concept of destroying light sources in order to be able to use the Darkness is an interesting idea, well fitting into the whole concept of the Darkness- character development system is not overwhelming the whole game - there is no point in maxing out character except for pure fun- some abilities give a lot of tactical advantages and possibilities - black holes can be of great help and autoaiming provided by one of high tier abilities, even while lasting about 5 seconds, can make the difference- last levels in hell are very nice and atmosphericCons:- the plot is kind of dumb if you're not into The Darkness comic books - Darkness says something, blablabla, Angelus blablabla, Brotherhood blablabla, vengance yadayada, Jenny hurrdurr, so on and so forth- you cannot skip some cutscenes - this is really bad- well, considering this is a shooter there aren't many different weapons - pistol, revolver, desert eagle, two different shotguns, winchester (you have it for about 15 minutes), two or three smgs, two or three different assault rifles and that's all- guns can use ammo really fast and there are not really that many ammo boxes laying around so you can find yourself in a situation where you don't have any bullets to shoot- I think that the games relies too much on the finisher mechanics - need to replenish health? Use Finisher #1. Need to get some additional ammo - guessed it, Finisher #2. Considering that uzis and other guns do use ammo pretty fast you may find yourself in a situation that you try to finish enemies with Finisher #1 or #2- special abilities are fun to use, but recharge slow and you don't really need them - they help, true, but they are not game changing abilities like for example slow motion in Max Payne 1.- this game is short (about 6-7 hours)As you can see I have described many cons so you may think that this is a mediocre game. By any means no, this is a really good game, I had a lot of fun playing it. There is New Game + option after beating the game, which adds some playtime if someone would like to go for the second run and max out character abilities. In the first run I think you can get 60-70% of all abilities so there is just enough reason to play the game for the second time. I just pass this option because I don't like to watch the same long cutscenes over again. Anyways... you can try Demo. Go and try it.---------- For anyone interested in joining in on completing your own backlog; check it out here - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog/discussions/5/530645446320364338/

content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												I have to say, it was a pretty good game, but it had flaws.  But it's not mindnumbing flaws.  Okay maybe one with the whole getting stuck in the vent, but still, I like the story, the characters, and while the graphics are more of the cartoony side, it is based off the comics.  So it makes sense.  It played well, and it has many cool things to do with two dark tenticles coming out of your back, and ripping your enemies to pieces.  Now, the flaws are that you can get stuck at certain parts in the game, which is weird how to fix it.  The story and gameplay is quite short.  It took me like 7 hours to beat it.  Not bad.  It can get boring after a while, because it's not really a huge variety of enemies.  The boss fights are not bad, and some are actually pretty cool.  And for the game to explore, it's very linear.  Not much to explore around the house, but you can chat with them.  Everything else outside, well, you can explore a bit to find the relics, but it's not hard to find.  It's just there, or in a corner somewhere.  I'm a bit ticked that I didn't get a single achievement during the whole play.  I even beat it, and it treats it like I wasn't playing it at all.  Stupid achievement system Steam has.  But I shouldn't let it bother me.  I've enjoyed the game, but I kind of recommend the first one more.  It's a little better, and it's much longer.  I still do recommend this game.  Get it when it's on sale or something.

												Frankly, with The Darkness II, I wasn't really expecting much. Probably just another demon fueled super action shooter right? Wrong. Well, right AND wrong. content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												The Darkeness II is not perfect. But I think its flaws dont outweigh what I like, so here we are. I would reccomend the game on sale, as it is wont to go because the combat is fast paced and fun. Sometimes theres a little too little ammo, and especially when enemies can disable your darkness powers this makes some areas a bit too hard, but the combat is fun, fast and brutal. The guns are tight, the darkness controls well, and the cell-shaded look is pretty good looking, especially considering this is based off of a comic book, as well as allowing some odd character desgin, like victor. The villians are vile, and normally I would say this is an attempt to make jackie seem like the better guy-and to a large degree thats true, but the game also never really pretends jackies perfect, so its not as obnoxious as it normally is. The story is ok, not great but not awful, and after reading some of the comic book plot summary, the veering away seems like a good choice. Everything is pretty solid, though I think they could have expanded the story and world a bit more and it would've fleshed it out a bit more.  Perhaps they couldve, but this games biggest problem probably had something to do with that-length. The game is just too damn short, and considering I enjoyed that it makes me sad that this was the case. The length is not ok, the FOV needs to be adjustable-this game is best on PC for the number of buttons that you use in combat, and not having a more adjustable FOV is unnacceptable. Also on PC, there are still bugs that don't let you get through certain areas unless you turn on Vsync, which makes the game look blurry if you leave it on by accident. Thats not ok, escpecially in this day and age of patching. The co-op is enjoyable, though the characters are all flat stereotypes, and  I can understand accusations of racism, though  I chalk it up to laziness more than anything. Still its a fun game, and I would highly reccomend it, though it may make you sad when you beat it to realize they may not make another one, considering the silence around it. Fingers crossed they do.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												I beat the game on normal difficulty in 6.5 hours. It's a solid FPS in the same league as Bulletstorm, Shadow Warrior, Call of Juarez: Gunslinger, and the like.Aiming is precise, enemies don't take entire clips to kill (as long as you have good aim), you're rewarded for more challenging kills with more ugprade points, and it's overall a story that makes you want to keep playing to see what happens.There's still a few things that might've been better about this game. Towards the end, as you start fighting stronger enemies, they start to feel like bullet sponges unless you are pretty much only shooting for their heads (a practice I highly recommend). Also, I felt like the special powers didn't really work well with the gunplay. For most fights, I just found some cover at a choke point and shot enemies in the head one by one - no need for special powers. If the upgrades integrated more with the shooting and were less strictly melee, I might've enjoyed that aspect of the game more and found it to be less repetitive. They also could've encouraged people to adopt a more run-and-gun style of play by including enemies or mechanics that make it difficult to just camp in one spot for the entire game and providing you with more mobility options. I felt that running around and trying to melee enemies wasn't a very viable tactic compared to camping and shooting because enemies could get so many shots on you before you close the gap.Other than that, the length is great. I don't feel like sections get too repetitive or feel like they're going on too long.If you like FPS games, you'll almost certainly like this. I would say it's not quite as good as Bullet Storm, Shadow Warrior, or call of Juarez: Gunslinger, but I definitely liked it more than Wolfenstein: New Order.

I'd appreciate more threatening places to go when you're not walking around the city.  The first one put you in the middle of a war with no explanation. The first one put you in a fight against the darkness. This one..... you get a schitzo-hospital and a "you're having a delusion" storyline.... eh.... been done before. content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												I never played the first Darkness game, released in 2007, as it was a PS3/Xbox 360 exclusive and I have owned neither console at the time of writing. Despite my lack of familiarity with the franchise, it appeared recently during a Steam sale as if by fate, and my eye was instantly captured by the dark and gritty art style. And it stayed there until I emerged victorious at the other end of the story, having followed the continuing exploits of mafia hitman Jackie Estacado as he seeks to prevent his consumption by the ruinous power known solely as The Darkness.So let’s begin as always with the graphical style. Playing through The Darkness 2 is like traversing the pages of a comic book, hardly surprising given the series is based on the comic of the same name. Colours pop from the screen, with particularly vivid blues, reds and purples to contrast with the very dark setting. Everything looks heavily saturated in the almost cel-shaded art style, which combines with some truly excellent dynamic lighting effects, ensuring that your experience will be superbly visceral and gritty.My ears were treated remarkably well by the soundtrack, a very noir-style orchestral affair. Each element of sound balances properly against all others, a common issue that I notice during many games. This is extremely noticeable here, with background music swelling and retreating depending on how much damage Jackie is taking in a given moment, giving way to a thudding heartbeat which serves as a warning of your untimely demise. I must also commend the voice acting in general, typical movie mobster tough-guys played convincingly but not over-the-top enough to sour the experience. Special mention goes out to the portrayal of your quintessentially British darkling companion - his cockney twang and incredibly colourful vocabulary is perfectly executed, providing some fantastic comic relief during your adventure.And what an adventure! The Darkness manifests as two enormous tentacles protruding from Jackie’s back which can be used for all sorts of nasty things, such as throwing objects with lethal force, smashing through obstacles, or even simply just rending your enemies in twane with reckless abandon. Whatever floats your evil boat. Of course as a hitman you can wield a variety of weapons in addition to your shadowy appendages, making you a pretty lethal killing machine. Want to casually rip away your enemies’ shields and spray them with two machine guns at once? No problem. I did find managing all my combat options a little confusing during hectic gunfights, and you do get used to it a little as the game progressed, but even by the end I was still making mistakes so prepare to practice a bit.In addition to the aforementioned bringers of destruction, The Darkness also generously provides you with supernatural abilities that can be exchanged for essence, obtained for defeating enemies, and be creative in your killing! You’ll get more essence for rapid or spectacular death-dealing, which in turn unlocks more fantastical slaughter options. Make sure to avoid the light though, as your tendrils will retreat when exposed to it and you’ll be relying solely on conventional weaponry until you do something to remedy the situation or can retreat back into the cover of the shadows and resume your rampage of gory destruction once more.The game isn’t terribly long, and I beat the main story on normal difficulty in around five hours, but there is a little more to be had, including a New Game+ mode wherein you retain any unlocked abilities from your first run and the Vendettas storyline, a co-op multiplayer mode featuring multiple Darkness-infused assassins each wielding their own unique weapon.If you’re a fan of fast-paced dark action titles, definitely don’t pass this up. If you can, I would recommend playing the first title beforehand as there were a couple of backstory elements alluded to during the game, but don’t let it put you off if you can’t - I thoroughly enjoyed myself regardless, gleefully leaving a trail of cruor and carnage in my wake.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												I beat the game on normal difficulty in 6.5 hours. It's a solid FPS in the same league as Bulletstorm, Shadow Warrior, Call of Juarez: Gunslinger, and the like.Aiming is precise, enemies don't take entire clips to kill (as long as you have good aim), you're rewarded for more challenging kills with more ugprade points, and it's overall a story that makes you want to keep playing to see what happens.There's still a few things that might've been better about this game. Towards the end, as you start fighting stronger enemies, they start to feel like bullet sponges unless you are pretty much only shooting for their heads (a practice I highly recommend). Also, I felt like the special powers didn't really work well with the gunplay. For most fights, I just found some cover at a choke point and shot enemies in the head one by one - no need for special powers. If the upgrades integrated more with the shooting and were less strictly melee, I might've enjoyed that aspect of the game more and found it to be less repetitive. They also could've encouraged people to adopt a more run-and-gun style of play by including enemies or mechanics that make it difficult to just camp in one spot for the entire game and providing you with more mobility options. I felt that running around and trying to melee enemies wasn't a very viable tactic compared to camping and shooting because enemies could get so many shots on you before you close the gap.Other than that, the length is great. I don't feel like sections get too repetitive or feel like they're going on too long.If you like FPS games, you'll almost certainly like this. I would say it's not quite as good as Bullet Storm, Shadow Warrior, or call of Juarez: Gunslinger, but I definitely liked it more than Wolfenstein: New Order.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												I have not played any of the multiplayer, so this review shall be focussed on the campaign aspect of the game.The darkness two is a gritty first person shooter. The unique selling point is that, in addition to being, in its own right, a relatively solid shooter, there is a supernatural twist. The darkness. The darkness is characterised well as a sort of demonic entity, though it takes a little time to get used to its over the top voice, which can be a little cheesy at times. In combat, the darkness powers are balanced well with the gunplay, you shouldn't find yourself being forced into a playstyle. However, particular strategies must be used for certain enemies. This can swing between being an enjoyable challenge to blisteringly frustrating. The skill tree in the game is relatively natural, and at no point during a first playthrough of a campaign should you find yourself overmighty, or conversely, ill-equipped to face the challenges of the game. One play-though didn't complete my skill wheel, so there is replay value if you feel like returning to collect all of Jackie's skills. The story is appropriately cartoonish and absurd, though this doesn't stop it from remaining dark and looming in tone. It is possibly more unsettling precisely due to it being surreal. The morbid atmosphere is reflected well in the gameplay, which incorporates sadistic (and satisfying) feats of violence wherever possible. One such mechanic that was absent from the first game is that of “executions”. These finishing moves allow Jackie to tear enemies apart in monstrously visceral ways. It is wonderful to give that guy that's been annoyingly shooting you across the map, while you've been killing mooks, exactly what is coming to him. The support characters are not bad, and aren't difficult to appreciate. That being said, there were very little surprises in the story, and this feels like a game that could have done with a really good twist.It's good fun, but it won't blow you away: 6/10

content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												This is an amazing game. So much so that I made it my player photo. While the campaign is a little short, it is a really great story, and one that almost made me cry near the end at a certain character's death. The gameplay is also amazing, it is so much fun to slice'n'dice hordes of enemies to pieces, and those executions, while brutal, are great. You can pick up car doors and billboards as shields which can then be thrown to bisect and decapitate enemies. Iron scafolding poles, pool sticks and parking meters can be thrown to impale enemies. A favourite ability of mine is the ground slam, done by knocking an enemy up and then down again quickly with the demon arms to insta-kill and cause a shockwave that knocks nearby enemies over. I have heard reviews say that "gore can only sustain a game for so long" but even if the executions were all that made this game great, I have put over 50 hours into this thing and not gotten bored of trisecting enemies yet. The vendetta's mode are also good, focussing less on being an almighty shadow god, and more on teamwork, seeing as each character only has one of Jackie's abilities. The relics are  also worth having a look for, as they each have an interesting backstory, told by the anxiety ridden Johny Powell. All in all this game is great, with only its relative shortness (and some unskippable cutscenes) holding it back from being amazing. 9/10

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												The Darkness II is a pretty solid FPS. If you know anything about the first game, you know that the first one isn't on PC. Well, two years after the events of the first game, two years after Jackie Estacado takes revenge on Paulie Franchetti for killing his gf, Jenny, and attempting to assasinate him, Jackie is the mob boss of the Franchettie family. In the beginning of the game, the Darkness is dormant within Jackie, the Darkness being a supernatural extension that has transferred itself on the Estacado family line. The story of The Darkness II follows Jackie surviving an assassination attempt in which he awakens the Darkness and hunts down those who attacked him. Unbeknownst to him, someone had set out to kill him or take him alive in order to obtain thd Darkness for themselves. Basically, Jackie uses his resources and his mafia friends to hunt down this group of people, not going to go into to much detail, crazy spoilers on that.The plot was pretty good, but a bit repetitive. There wasn't too much of a story arc, as it really is rather straightforward; that is until you start to hallucinate yourself in an asylum and much later in the game, hell. Stuff does get bizarre, such as Jackie hallucinating Jenny while in the middle of missions. Even though the Darkness is making him go mad and wants to believe she's real, he understands that he's not exactly in control of his powers.Well, anyway, the story was good, but it had it's flaws. Onto the technical side of things, like gameplay. Rather simple as far as shooting goes, you've all probably played FPS games so I'm not gonna bother getting into detail. I do want to talk about the tentacles that extend from Jackie's body. They're awesome. I mean, they're evil, but they're great as weapons. You can slice people apart, hold them in the air and flay them, eat their hearts for health (which by the way does mean there's a health bar), you can also control how you slice based on what direction you swing the right stick in, or if you're using a kb/m, it would be the mouse. Graphics were interesting, they using cel shaders for this one to get that comic book style as the game is based on a series of comics, while the first game went for a more realistic look. There are, at points, where the stuttering was bad, mainly in Jackie's penthouse. Otherwise, the framerates were good. A few other bugs here and there, but not enough to say the game is buggy.Anyway.8.3/10Oh, and stay for the post credits scene.

Posted: January 31, 2015
												I never finished the first Darkness because it wasn't on PC and I suck at shooters on my PS3. So fortunately there was a previously on Darkness at the start of this game, but to be honest it wasn't very detailed so I had to go to wikipedia to find out what happened in the first Darkness.Regardless of that, it doesn't take you long to be pulled into the story. The Darkness 2 does a great job of immersing you into the feelings and thoughts of the main character, which is a rarity in modern day gaming. Often you are very disconected from the story and the emotions of the characters. Lately, the only other game I have played that did such a great job of pulling you in, emotionally, was BioShock Infinite.Beyond the story, which while nothing especially impressive (mostly due to the fact the game is only 6 hours long), what is there is enough and is well orcestrated. The most impressive feat is the game's ability to put you in the shoes of the main character and really doubt what is real and what is not real (in the game).The gameplay is top notch though and if you enjoy shooters where you run from one area to the next and have to clear all the waves of enemies, then this is a game for you. The gunplay is fun and has impact and the tentacles are well implemented so that they are not overpowered and yet are still very fun and exciting to use. I found myself using primarily guns but definitely had to use my powers frequently to stay in the fight. I was glad though that the powers did not dominate the gameplay so that you simply use the powers when you feel the need and are not forced to constantly use the powers. In some games where you have powers they dominate the other gameplay mechanics to the point that you find yourself only using the powers and nothing else. Fortunately, this is not the case in the Darkness 2.The graphics are not impressive or special, but they make up for what they lack in the style, which once you've played the game to completion the style will make sense. A lot of people were surprised when they first revealed the first gameplay video of The Darkness 2 because of the art style they had used. But there is a definite reason for it and it only further helps immerse you into the world of confusion that the main character is living in.The soundtrack is great and the voice work is top quality. All in all, it is a very fun game with a decent story that manages to pull you in and leaves you desiring more.Would definitely recommend giving this game a spin! It is a great purchase and a great experience to play through once or even twice! In addition there are even some co-op missions to further the experience, so if you have a friend to play it with it will add a few more hours of quality gameplay.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Download size: Less than 10 gbPlay time: About 6 hours for campaignThe Darkness 2 is based on a popular comic book that I haven’t read, and the first Darkness game never made it to Steam/PC. Fortunately, I found the story strong enough to stand alone so I didn’t feel like I was missing any important backstory. There’s a “previously on the Darkness” cutscene that you can watch upon starting a new game, and there’s actually some “talking head” scenes between game chapters where the protagonist Jackie talks to the player as if he’s narrating his autobiography, so you should be caught up pretty quick.You play Jackie Estacado, a kind of Mafia boss who has sworn off using the Darkness, a demonic entity that inhabits his body and gives him superhuman powers at the cost of his soul. Too bad for Jackie, a powerful mysterious group comes to town determined to reclaim the Darkness, which they used to be caretakers for. Since the Darkness can only be given up willingly, the only way for them to get it back is by turning Jackie’s life upside down and torturing him into giving it up. This means war.The Darkness 2 is a first person shooter with the gimmick of having 2 Darkness tentacles that you can use to grab objects or slash at enemies with. You can also dual wield many one handed guns, so essentially you have 4 limbs to kill people with (2 guns + 2 tentacles). The Darkness also gives you a few powers that you unlock through purchasing in darkness “shrines” found throughout the world. You get dark essence by killing enemies and finding special artifacts, then spend the essence at the shrines on skills and upgrades. It’s not an open world game, you just find the shrines all over the place along the way. There are 4 skill trees to spend your essence in, but you won’t find enough essence in one playthrough to purchase everything. You’ll need to use the New Game + option and grind for more essence. One of the key game elements is the need to destroy light sources (lamps, street lights, etc.) since bright lights will inhibit the Darkness, causing your screen to lens flare out and go black and white. Your powers and Darkness tentacles are also disabled when this happens so if you’re playing one of the higher difficulty levels you need to snipe out lights before you get too close. The Darkness 2 uses a regenerating health system like Gears of War or any of the Modern Warfare games so if you’re taking too much damage, get behind something for a few seconds to recover.Pros:+Excellent story with some twisted enemy bosses. The boss battles aren’t spectacular, but you’ll probably really hate those dudes by the time you get to fight them.+Pretty good graphics, which kind of remind me of the Borderlands games but with more detail. There are a number of death animations for various ways that you can use the Darkness to execute weakened enemies. The tentacle arm executions can be gruesome. +The game has a long co-op campaign called Vendettas, though I have only tried a few of the missions (they run parallel to the single player campaign with 4 new characters). The Vendetta missions have their own bosses and you can build up character specific skill trees with dark essence gathered in multiplayer games.Cons:-There are a ton of characters and even though I’ve played through the game twice, I only know the names of 3-4 of them. I’m sure most of them were in the first game so they’re just making appearances in part 2. They aren’t all that important though, so no sweat.-The game is very short at under 6 hours for your first playthrough, but this doesn’t include the Vendetta campaign. It means you probably need a co-op partner to get the full experience. For your second/third playthrough (with all your maxed out powers) if you skip the cutscenes you can probably finish the single player campaign in less than 5 hours.All in all, the Darkness 2 is a great game and well worth the low price you can find it at. It was even in the $1 tier of a Humble Bundle a few months back so you can probably get it cheap. The game’s highlight is the single player story, and you probably won’t find many people playing multiplayer nowadays.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2013
												The Darkness 2 is what I like to classify as a power-fantasy game. You will often find yourself wading into enemies, shooting and tearing your enemies to pieces all around you. Health and cover are not a huge issue as you can tear the hearts out of fallen/staggered foes for a health boost on the fly. The game also boasts what they call "quad-wielding"; allowing you to use your demon tendrils as an extra 2 hands. This lets you actively grab items and enemies, hold shields or use the tendrils as a close range whip; all while keeping your actual hands free to fire your guns. The combat is fast and furious and feels very satisfying. An interesting mechanic is the fact that your Darkness powers don't work in the light, and your enemies in the mid-late parts of the game know this. Enemies will come at you with shoulder mounted spotlights and employ flashbangs to try and slow you down. It keeps it interesting as the enemy with the light instantly becomes your priority regardless of the armored shotgunners 10 feet away from you. The story is engaging and fun, but is not too long. You play the head of a mafia family with powers known as "The Darkness" as your organization engages in all out war with an ancient dark cult intent on stealing your powers and killing anyone in their way. Definitely not a plot you come across often! Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who thinks this sounds interesting as I had lots of fun with it!
