content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Overall, The Darkness 2 is a good game, but it has a variety of frustrating details that make the game much less fun, and generall my willingness to pay attention to the story.1. Controls - There are several boss fights as well as a bunch of ordinary encounters that require you to quickly move out of the way or dodge something. The problem is that you move like a pregnant boat. This isn't really that much worse than a lot of first person shooter games, but those games don't want you to dodge.2. Nonsense - You can run through the game getting blasted by shotguns and machine guns and survive. I don't have a problem with this. After all, in the context of the story you should be able to. The problem is that whenever the story wants you for some reason a quick flash or lights or a shotgun blast put you on the ground unable to move.3. Lights - I really do like the mechanic that you can't use any of your powers in the light--that is the way that it is in the comic after all--but that game randomly desides that some lights can't be destroyed. So, you spend a great deal of the game destroying one light after another only to be held up in the level by a light with a metal grate over it. Annoying.4. Story - The story deviates significantly from the comic, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. There are however two main problems with how the story is told in this game. First, there are a greate deal of boring dialogue that you have to pay attention to, to have any understanding of what is happening in the story. This becomes grating. Second, the story relys very heavily on common tropes. Vengence for the murder of your girlfriend. Vengence for *spoiler*'s murder. A dark broodin man of violence, fighting his inner demons. It's been done.

I usually don't do this with games, but I just started skipping them after a while--that and all the dialouges.  The border rendered graphics are pretty cool, but overall the game falls way short.  In the end, I would not recommend this game.

Good physics.3. Good voice and animated acting (the mental-patient who thinks he's adolf Hitler comes to mind.)But seriously, games (and movies and TV shows) that takes the road of sex, violence, and swearing to appear mature are getting really really old. Violence: you get to rip your enemies in so many ways - vertical, horizontal, pull their spines and skulls out through their♥♥♥♥♥ Geez. Tone it down several notches and instead give its atmosphere (and the music) a boost. Ever heard of Alan Wake? There's Darkness there too and man did I feel that one.Sex: There are scenes of oral sex, sex from behind, moaning ala porn stars, and beating up women in the sexual context. References of snorting drugs from private parts of women I mean seriously.Music: Eh, so-so. Its ok. Does the job.Storyline: Pffft. Like, yeah right. Basically, the premise is - Light and Darkness are entities in an eternal battle. Great concept. Execution tries too much to be "cool". Too much in fact that it is the "thing" that makes it feel "immature" in its attempt to be "mature." If Light (The Angelus) is the opposite of The Darkness, then that means its as good as The Darkness is evil. Why then does it look like a cosplay hooker?Gameplay: The gun-combat is pretty ok by today's standards. Dual-wielding pistols and tactical assault pistols/rifles is awesome. Don't expect to dual-wield high-caliber weapons here though. You're a mob boss, not a mech.Atmosphere. The feeling of being too much indoors, even if you are outside, is too much in my opinion. Did I "feel" the darkness? I felt it when I played Alan Wake. Here, not at all. Even with the voice of The Darkness eerily speaking through my 7.1 surround gaming headset. Would The Darkness like some losenges? ^_^.I'm glad its a short game.Yeah, just when you thought that you cannot be desensitized any further...you know what I mean?CONCLUSION: Take away the sex, violence, and cussing, and this game is ziltch.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												(Note: I didn't play the first The Darkness game nor do I have experience with The Darkness comic books)At its best The Darkness II is a very stylish game. The comic book origins of this title really come out in a positive way in that regard. Sadly the gameplay does not live up to the presentation aspect of this title.At the very best you can call The Darkness II an above average shooter. It does nothing special which might sound weird considering how you basically are a semi-god demon monster with tentacles coming out of you ready to rip enemies and the envinroment alike apart. It's just very basic under the shiny shell. You're not really encouraged to utilize your demonic skills and when you do it just doesn't feel very cool. Naturally darkness is weak to light which brings us to a very frustrating gameplay mechanic. Remember how everyone loves getting hit by flashbangs in shooters? Me neither. The Darkness II manages to take this to another level. Light makes you incapable of using your demon skills which in practice means whatever plan you had with impaling an enemy with that spear-like object you can forget. The real pain starts when enemies start using light against you. This results in many chaotic moments where you just have no idea where to shoot to regain some level of control over the game. The blinding effect of light is way overdone and will make you feel frustrated. When you being the badass mob leader demon you are have to stop every time coming to a new area to snipe off lightbulbs with your pistol you know something is not done right. To top this off the game has a bug which frequently makes motion blur "reverse". What this means is that everytime the motion blur should be off it's on and vice versa. It's not enough to destroy the experience but it's annoying.The story is The Darkness II's best part. It's not magnificient but it will keep you interested. Characters are solid with a few really standing out. That said I felt very unsatisfied with the ending. As a stand-alone product it doesn't really work. After about 7 hours of singleplayer campaign you don't have much to do. You can hunt down relics (with some really interesting descriptions as a reward I have to say!) or try a harder difficulty level. The game also features the "mandatory online element" where four of your friends take on separate missions from main story. With no real story I had absolutely no motivation in trying my hands at those the gameplay being mediocre. If you want a multiplayer co-op shooter I'm sure you can think of better ways of spending your time and money.After all the complaining you might think I hate the game but this is not the case at all. Beyond the presentation it's just not anything special. Mediocrity is not a crime and I'd say The Darkness is definitely worth it if you can find a great deal. At anywhere close to the full price I wouldn't consider it.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												The Darkness II is emblematic of so many of the worst narrative and design concepts of gaming as a medium.It’s a game so obsessed with its own mythos, so completely devoid of self-awareness, and so appallingly misogynistic that it is often actively painful to witness. The entirety of The Darkness II seems designed around alliterative bullet points: “guns, girls, and gore.” In many ways then this isn’t terribly different from so many shooters, but where The Darkness II sets itself apart is in how much it revels in its own stupidity and filth.It’s going to be important later on in this review, so just so we’re all caught up let’s quickly run through the basic premise behind The Darkness II: brooding protagonist has nothing to live for; girlfriend gives him purpose; girlfriend is killed to get back at protagonist; protagonist has nothing to live for and decides to kill everyone. Somewhere in there is also the fact that our protagonist, mafia kingpin Jackie Estacado, has a demon (the eponymous Darkness) living inside him which gives him superpowers and mostly makes him invincible. From here on events unfold as they typically do, with the introduction of a cult hell-bent on taking Jackie’s darkness (because that’s what cults do) causing all sorts of chaos, as Jackie all the while holds up inside his head lamenting the loss of his girlfriend and showing emotions™.Though its stereotypical setup might lead you to believe otherwise, The Darkness II’s biggest problem isn’t in its rudimentary plot (though that’s definitely one of them) but in how its only means of creating conflict and motivation for its characters is through violence toward women. Jackie’s girlfriend, Jenny, is fridged before the prologue is finished (a carryover from the last game) and from that point on The Darkness II kills literally every single female character in the game for the sake of motivating Jackie, all while neglecting to give them even the smallest bit of personality, as ultimately their only reason for inclusion (beyond to be fridged) is to be objectified and tortured.What’s possibly even worse than the way The Darkness II treats women is in how it attempts to mask its misogyny under faux-emotional maturity and narrative sophistication. Developer Digital Extremes dedicates a not-insignificant amount of time to attempting to humanize the relationship between Jackie and Jenny, but because Jenny exists merely as a narrative prop with all the personality of a perverted body pillow these segments feel like little more than gross reminders of how one sided and shallow their relationship actually is. It doesn’t help that Jackie is something beyond unlikable with a penchant for juvenile philosophy, as he sits in the dark gun in hand and recites odes to his own amorality. The Darkness II was never a game with a penchant for subtlety, but its writing is so horrendous and convenient that it can’t even scrape by as merely clichéd, but instead doubles down on its tropes, on its misogyny, on its pornographic love of meaningless violence, and then tries to sell it to you as mature storytelling.Some might say this is just staying true to The Darkness’ comic book roots, but justifying The Darkness II’s narrative disaster through its mirroring of another work does little but damn them both. And to that point there is little about The Darkness II that speaks to its awareness of the tropes it’s employing, as it is so abundantly self-serious that it is impossible to enjoy it as knowingly dumb or comically grotesque the way one might enjoy a B-movie. In the few cases where The Darkness II tries to introduce some levity to its proceedings it predictably punches down, with sexist and ableist jabs that are neither clever nor shocking, but just as cheap and untasteful as the rest of the game.And low and behold if this isn’t as exceedingly routine a shooter as its narrative deserves. The Darkness II’s main mechanical hook is using your two demon arms in conjunction with more ordinary guns to create a sort of synergistic ultraviolence, but in application your demonic appendages are little more than glorified swords and grappling hooks. There was a lot of room for The Darkness II to create interesting encounters focused around forcing you to think creatively with the one thing that sets this apart from any other shooter, but The Darkness II is wholly and unapologetically married to its power fantasy mundanity, and so you are left with room after room of decidedly uninteresting grunts to tear your way through as if the thrill of watching your demon arms rip a man in half is enough to make combat interesting.The Darkness II’s demon arms reminded me a lot of Bioshock’s plasmids, but where Bioshock used its plasmids to setup interesting dynamics between you and your enemies, The Darkness II is focused on nothing but accommodating as aggressive a playing style as possible. And that’s not inherently bad, but there is nothing about how The Darkness II plays that makes that aggression satisfying. The shooting is loose, your arms are overpowered, the enemies are tedious and ordinary, and you’re constantly being funneled down the tightest of corridors. The Darkness II tries to counteract this by implementing a kill based scoring system reminiscent of Bulletstorm, but it lacks the depth and creativity that made kills in that game so entertaining, settling here for a narrow range of possibilities which mostly serve to distinguish between gun and darkness kills.The Darkness II’s mechanics would feel like a missed opportunity if the entirety of the framework surrounding them wasn’t so unsalvageable. The Darkness II is a game reeking of the worst sorts of narrative based sexism, marrying its violent tendencies with misogynistic conveniences, and the sort of discriminating carelessness that video games so often try to pass off as a sign of their maturity. To the contrary The Darkness II is one of the least innovative and sophisticated games I have played in a very long time, seeming to exist for the very sake of regressing videogames back to a time when nobody questioned why every female character has enormous breasts or why they are constantly getting kidnapped.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												OK, why was I so disappointed with this game? Three main points spoiled this game for me. I won't go on about graphics, they're fine. Decent engine, decent artists etc. Game mechanics were fine. The menu system was a little annoying but you get used to that. Music was typically horrible but thankfully you can turn it off unlike some games(yes Halo 4, I'm talking about you) So what didn't I like? Read on.Firstly, cinematics...lots and lots of cinematics. The annoying kind where you can't move and the characters talk seemingly forever when all they have to do is say, 'go out the door and shoot everyone you see.'. You can hardly travel 100 meters without being dragged into some scripted action sequence or some long boring dialogue. Judging by the amount of positive reviews this game receives I assume most people don't mind this. I don't understand. I find it very tedious. Don't get me wrong, I like storylines. I'm happy to sit and watch little cinematics every now and then. I just hate the game being interrupted every 5 minutes just so someone can tell you to walk down some stairs or whatever. OK, finished gripe no.1Second gripe; the demon, serpent, tentacle,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥things. I assumed they were something you could bring up to use when you needed them. Nope, they're there the whole time. Fine if you like that sort of thing, IE great big dangly appendages cluttering up the screen, and I understand that some people do like that sort of thing, just not me. Oh, and apart from their basic intrusiveness, they're just silly. A gangster with tentacles, spare me please.Thirdly, the sidekick. Again, some people obviously like annoying little halfwit sidekicks running around saying annoying half witted things. I just happen to not. The last half hour of my abortive attempt at playing this game was spent shooting it. The only joy I had in this game was discovering that you can shoot the sidekick, though regrettably he does regenerate.So there you have it. I wanted to like this game. I loved Sandman and Hellblazer and other stuff back in the day. I knew it would be silly. It's graphic novel/comic book type horror, of course it's going to be silly. Unfortunately excessive cinematics, non-retractable tentacles and a sidekick modelled on a brain damaged teenage metal head made this game unplayable for me. Sorry Digital Extremes. I tried.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Severely dissapointed with this game, although I may be a tad biased.First of all, the second installment of The Darkness is nothing like it's predecessor; save the generous heaps of blood and gore and the bone-chilling voice of The Darkness itself. It's style has been completely revamped, sporting a much more "cartoony" look that resembles the comics well. However, this style change is not just skin-deep. See, the original Darkness game was unique in the sense that it actually managed to be better than it's originial content: the comics. It ditched the more ham-fisted aspects of the story that were introduced far too quickly (conveniently evil cults, an overly obvious antithesis of the Darkness, and many more things that made it far more "fantasy" than anything else. The first game changed all of this. The story was far more dark and grounded in reality, and you truly felt as though you were the the most powerful person in the world because half of the time, you were fighting low-life thugs and corrupt cops.  Enemies cowered in fear when you unleashed your demons because they had never seen anything like it. This time around, you are fighting a great deal of enemies who seem to be more aware of what's going on than you do (just less powerful), and that takes away a great deal of the thrill. Fighting terrified mobsters was easily my favorite part of The Darkness 2, but as soon as the evil cult shows up with all of their mystical weapons and hardware, I lost interest. I was just in another comic-inspired game. This change of style also poses continuity problems because altough the tone of the game has changed COMPLETELY, references to the first game are made constantly. This tethers you to a universe that looks and feels completely different, and the story experience thus feels less cohesive. It's a sequel, but it's not. It is it's own game, but it's not. (this is ofcourse assuming that you played the first game).The gameplay is where the fun begins and eventually commits suicide. The gunplay is tight and responsive; you can use your demon arms to cut apart enemies (sometimes clean in half); and you can even tear doors off of cars and use them as a shield, whipping it at unsuspecting enemies when you're bored. You can even pick up construction poles and pin enemies to walls with them. To make this even BETTER, you can actually do most of this in a matter of seconds if not all at once.  Sounds fun, right? Absolutely. So where does it all fall apart?It falls apart when the game introduces a scoring and execution system.Remember Bulletstorm? In case you didn't, Bulletstorm introduced the concept of rewarding players for finding creative ways of killing enemies. This ranged from pulling off headshots to literally kicking them into environmental hazards riddled throughout the area. The Darkness 2 mimics this minus the environments............kinda lame.......Either way, straight up shooting enemies to death (even if you pull off a headshot) doesn't reward you with NEARLY as many points as performing an execution does. As a matter of fact, executions are easily the best way to get points. On top of this, you are rewarded even further depending on which of the three TYPES of executions you performed. These can reward you with extra health, ammo, or a darkness shield. This essentially translates to: if the game gets too tough; shoot some guy in the nuts, perform a health execution (that you can't be hurt during), rinse and repeat. But I honestly think the extra points from executions is the worst offender. I loved experimenting with all of the potential options for carnage that I had access to, but I innevitably found that the point system pressured me into a playstyle that prioritized points over fun. The COOP? It's a tacked-on piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥maranated in stale beer and the tears of young orphans.Really. Thats all I have to say about the coop.Bottom Line: You a goreaholic and need to see some people torn apart by demonic powers? Wait till this game goes on sale, and I assure you that it will not dissapoint in that regard. However, if you are looking for an experience that rivals that of the first game, you may find yourself as dissapointed as me.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												This game it is not a complete disaster, even though I do not personally recommend it.It's not recommended only if you've played the original The Darkness on console. In any case: this is what I call a missed opportunity. The Darkness II tries to continue the adventures of the unlucky Jackie Estacado, tormented by the death of his girlfriend Jenny, with The Darkness itself to spice the things up. As written in the comic books, Jackie is the carrier of an antique evil force that humans passed on from generations to generations constantly fighting its counterpart, the Light. In this chapter we'll se a mysterious cult who is pursuing him to steal his mystical power. Unfortunately, the plot is the weakest part of the experience, and it is a shame, because the gameplay is satisfying. Being the Darkness is a good experience, you can feel like an overpowered creature who can slaughter and kill everything it breathes. Although there are few powers that  you can play with, they're fun to use. Also the environment interaction is pretty good, in fact you can take various object with your demonic limb and throw them to your foes with enjoyable and squishy results. The game encourages you to do so in many different ways, as you can earn Dark Essence (XP) to unlock powers and abilities.The gunplay instead, it's sufficient: no recoil, the weapons sound and feel all over the same. The only difference you can tell about them is the fire ratio. It suffers from the modern FPS syndrome: high difficulty = enemies have lots of health points, so going further with the game usually is just trying and failing with a poor challenge. At least there's not regenerating health because you have to eat hearts from dead enemies in order to replenish it.There is also a limited multiplayer coop mode with 4 characters to choose from with different skills and abilities, but it adds nothing to the experience, it's just another excuse to shoot everything. Maybe this mode was built in order to extend the game length, because the singleplayer campaign is very short (about 6 hours).Do yourself a favor: if you own a PS3 or Xbox360 go and grab a copy of the first game. You won't be disappointed.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												"The Darkness" was an amazing experience that i'll never forget. I'd even go as far as to say when someone asks me what my favorite game is/was that "The Darkness" is my favorite game, just because of how much of a lasting impression it left on me. As far as I know, it never got a PC release like TD2, but if you have a console, it's a slightly flawed gem but I highly recommend it. ...HOWEVER, The Darkness 2 is just awful. I mean, it's a competent shooter, and by the standard of just fps in general it's largely inoffensive aside from some obvious bugs, one of which was really annoying where my character would flat out get stuck in a vent until i pushed the steam screenshot button; it was the weirdest almost game breaking glitch i've ever seen in all of my years of playing video games. ...But that's not why you shouldn't play this game. If you're a fan of the first like I am or ever plan on playing the first, stay away from this game. It adds a bunch of♥♥♥♥♥♥to the canon that may have been following the graphic novel it's based on better, sure, but the first game did it's own interpetation and did it extremely well, and excels in every concieveable way over the second game from graphics, to story, to pacing, to gameplay in general. When i finished playing the Darkness 1 i was left with a feeling of "Wow, that was a great game." but after finishing this i was left with "I wish i could ♥♥♥♥ing unplay this game, it was awful and repetitive and did something with Jenny's character that♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me right the ♥♥♥♥ off. This whole game could have never happened and it would have changed nothing."In a nutshell, if you EVER plan on playing The Darkness, steer clear of this game at all costs. If you don't, there are still better games you can buy with your money.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2013
												Unimpressive across the board. The biggest problem with The Darkness 2 is the pacing. There is so much exposition in it. Every 10 minutes the game grinds down to a halt to have a drawn out dull conversation about nothing interesting at all. It gets tedious real fast. There must be two hours of dialogue in the game and it's all essentially meaningless nonsense. Sadly, it's the kind of game where it's really short and I'm grateful for it being short. It was only around 6 hours to finish the campaign. Another problem is the mechanic of the game that your character is super sensitive to light. Whenever there are bright lights around, the screen gets blurry and it's almost impossible to tell what's going on or where the light source is. It just makes the game confusing. The most thrilling part of the game was when Blind Melon's "No Rain" started playing in the background during one part. The graphics look like a 360 launch game. There's a bunch of screen tearing if vertical sync isn't turned one. The enemies arn't very fun to fight. The game can be really gross too. There's a bunch of  over the top gore and this game actually made me tired of hearing the f-word. A game like this really makes me appreciate, the nowadays, fewer and far between good FPS' out there. Don't bother with The Darkness 2.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Junk. Pure and simple, especially if you enjoyed the first one. The ideas are the same but the thing has lost its soul. Combat is awful, even though you have more powers, the combat is clunky and un-intuitive. You'll find yourself pressing buttons over and over during combat trying to just do or grab one thing but you'll often die because while you wanted to grab the guy to heal you just kept grabbing random thrown weapons. The story isn't as drawing as the first either, of course it's hard to get into a game when it isn't enjoyable to play. The game finally lost me at the boss battle with the crane and swifty. A truly horribly executed "arena" style boss battle that assaults you from every direction. No balance, no thought put into the execution, just bad. After ten tries I finally un-installed and moved on, back to Doom and Dishonored.        The game even looks like it took a step backwards, cell shading is a cop out. The first title played and looked better than this one.  In the end, if you want a great play, get the first Darkness, this is just a cheap shot at the wallet of fans of the first game, desperate to get a decent sequel to a very under rated title.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												The Darkness 2! Now with 2x more Darkness! Much WOW!Pros:-It's a first person shooter! OMG-It plays ok.-Controller support is always nice. Cons:-The protagonist is possessed by a demon. I was hoping it'd be an "off brand" creature if you will. Like spiderman's symbiote. Nope. -Supposedly a struggle against inner darkness. They hint at it. But the game is filled with loving camera angles of gory brutal executions and excessive bad language. Seems more like a celebration of darkness than a gripping struggle against inner darkness. -Aside from a few new mechanics, you've probably played this exact game before several times. It is another "story FPS the game" if you will. -Apparently only 5-6 hrs long, according to other reviewers. -How many FPS games do you need in your library? Why not buy a platforming game or a sports game or towerfall or something? Do you want a future where all games converge into only FPS?If you really want another shooter, compare this with Rainbow Six Vegas 2. Vegas 2's singleplayer is somewhat longer, has dynamic enemy ai, interesting level design, and has some people to play Terrorrist Hunt with for added replay value. The gunplay in Vegas 2 is also pretty compelling.(I played this for a half hour, I don't know why it sometimes looks like 0 hrs. ugh)

content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
												Darkness II succeeds to achieve fantastic story with fun gameplay, that is quite rare with nowadays shooters. It is based on dark adult comic book full of blood, swear words and one romantic story. Game adapts story from comic book very well and it is accesible to non-readers as well. It is full of twists and one meaningful goal - your loved one. It may sounds boring or "girllish" but actually game makes you really care about them. Mafia setting works too. Gameplay is trying to differentiate from other FPSs by giving you two tentacles which you can control. This combined with the gun and light mechanics provides enough combat variability throughout the 6 hour campaign. There is also a co-op mode (or you can play it solo too) that fills some gaps in story that werent that importatnt, called Vendettas, where you can take control of characters with special abilities instead of tentacles. Overall i think, that Darkness is the best singleplayer experience in its genre since Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare, if not better.

												Before continuing I want to offer a word of warning: The game is abysmally short. It's so short that one could mistake it for an expansion pack to an existing game.However, despite that rather huge shortcoming, it is a decent game that offers some interesting gameplay mechanics. The story is not shabby even though it deviates from the comic, but what will bring you back is the power of the Darkness. Although one could classify this game as a shooter it does offfer you the amazing power of the Darkness, which is only available, well, in darkness. This means that while you prowl in the shadows you are going to have some amazing powers. Playing through normal I felt almost like a god, and disposing your enemies with the powers at your fingertips is strangely satisfying.Ultimately this is a bargain game. Get it cheap and you will not regret it. It will offer 4-5 hours of fun gameplay that might even leave you waiting for a sequel that offers a bit more of what is presented.

												A STRONG sequel to one of my early favourites on the Xbox 360. The game uses a great cell-shadey look too it, which is not too much, and gives the thing a real stylish presentation. The integration of the Darkness' powers with the running-and-gunning feels really smooth, and there're some great animations when using the Darkness serpents. content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Campaign Review:The art style is a cross between Borderlands and the Godfather game (I know, go figure)The voice acting is top notch. It definitely helps you get attached to both Jenny and Jackie.The story was very well written, the dialogue was nothing short of excellent. Plenty of firearms choices -- nothing original though -- at least until the last level (not gonna spoil it though)The Darkness powers are AWESOME. You feel like a dark, f***ed up GOD. The kill animations are brutal to say the least. At one point or another, you'll find yourself ripping someone's spine out through their ♥♥♥♥♥♥. This game isn't for the weak of heart, in that regard.There are two endings -- but you can choose what you wish.My favorite character was a tie between the Darkling and Johnny. The Darkling is a british demon wearing a union jack shirt. He's nothing short of hilarious. He's very sarcastic and playing as him is a nice treat. Newman nailed him. That squirrelly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Johnny struck me as the tin-foil hat type and didn't feel very out of place in this type of game. He was a good addition. Onto my favorite aspect and my rating:My absolute favorite bits in this game had to be how DE tried very hard (and, for the most part, succeeded) to make you severely question which was real -- the asylum or the world with the Darkness.One of the endings -- I won't say which -- could make for an interesting sequel, but honestly I don't think It would last more than a couple hours.I give this game an 8 out of 10.  I got it on sale for $6, but for what I just played through... I'd say it's worth the full $32 dollar price tag

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												Traditional single-player FPS that mixes gunplay with the "Power of the Darkness". Obviously, as the title of the game implies, the darkness is what makes this game what it is. The two demons hanging over your shoulder mix suprisingly Very well with the gunplay aspect. Gunplay is traditional, but handled well, giving the player the choice of Dual-Weilding two different handheld weapons or sticking to one big gun (Shotgun, Assault Rifle, etc.), similar to Max Payne 3. Gameplay is fast paced and brutal, given the fact that your practicaly playing as a demon. Ripping people apart, decapitating, and even pulling someones spine out of their♥♥♥♥♥♥are all part of the disturbing yet oh-so-satisfying executions the player can bring. As far of the story goes, Its simple but gripping. Characters are interesting and are cleverly written, and the voice acting in this game is Outstanding. None of the characters feel out of place and are even humorus at appropriate times, epecially your AI companion, the Darkling. The only real problem with the game is its length. It can be completed in nearly 6-7 hours. There are relics you can collect during missions, but the secret hunting dosent add too much replayability by itself. Overall, the Darkness 2 is a very fun game and definatly not a waste of time. Definatly worth a buy during a sale or even a rent.OVERALL(+) Darkness/Gunplay combo works well(+) Story, Voice acting, Characters (Johnny Powell and the Darkling are probably the best)(+) Comic book style graphics work well for the games theme(+) Brutality is handled well(+) Secrets are interesting, worth finding(+) Refreshing change of pace from other generic shooters(-) Too Short(-) Not much replayability(-) Not much to do in-between missions(-) The Ending (It hints toward a third game)Final Score: 7.5/10

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												The angst-fueled action junkie's dream game: a first-person shooter where you're one part Scarface and one part Satan. It's goal is to make you feel like an unstoppable train of supernatural violence and it does so with sadistic glee. A mass of vaporous snakes surround the player that hack enemies to pieces, throw objects to crush or impale them, or drag them away to be executed in grisly fashion. Area-of-effects like insect swarms and black holes are showboatingly overpowered in their ability to rend apart large groups of enemies. Even the standard gunplay, which includes dual-wielded weapons, can be assisted by the Darkness in turning your gunshots into wisps of energy to reduce adversaries to soup. The environments have been simplified a great deal from the original and its stereotypical comic book plot and machismo grit are turned up way past eleven. Other action titles have tried to make you feel like a monstrous force of nature, but none of them are nearly as successful as The Darkness.

												This game is very unique and that's what I love about it. It is based off of a comic series where you play as a mob boss named Jackie who has inherited an ancient power known as "The Darkness," which is basically two tentacle-like creatures coming out of your back. 												As a fan of the original Darkness game, i was left wondering if the sequel would deliver on the same level. While the game is fun, it doesnt have the same emotional kick as the original. Though, it does try, and succeed to a point. The gameplay is solid, and standard FPS controls apply. Fighting entirely with the Darkness is exceedingly difficult to do, so you'll spend most of your time wielding guns. Unlike in the original, you can't simply impale an enemy with a darkness attack. Using the Darkness is however, extremely fun. I found myself trying to spear as many enemies onto a wall as possible with whatever object that came to hand. The execution styles i never used much, i tended to just perform health executions, and there are about three execution animations for each type. The game is bloody, and the graphics are enjoyable, though they're clearly meant to take on a more comic like feel, which it doesnt always succeed in. The game is surprisingly short in comparision to the original, and i finished it in just under five hours of play. I've logged more hours just trying to find collectables, and nailling enemies to walls. (Don't judge me!) it's a fun game overall, with a good amount of story depth, basic controls, and occasionally amusing dialogue. It's held back by how limited the Darkness powers are, in comparison to the comics, as well as how short the game is. Definitely good for a play, though maybe wait for it to be on sale.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												A brutal FPS with a few psychological thriller elements, the Darkness II is not for the faint of heart. The game puts you in the shoes of tormented mob boss Jackie Estacado, hereditary host of the malevolent supernatural being known only as the Darkness. Struggling to keep the evil contained within him, Jackie is pushed to his breaking point by a powerful organization interested in drawing that evil out. And so the game beings.With the Darkness unleashed Jackie is a force to be reckoned with. The Darkness is extremely powerful and dispatches of enemies in the cruelest and most horrifying ways imaginable, while at the same time nourishing Jackie and keeping him alive. The Darkness fears only one thing, the light. So whenever you see a source of light, you should destroy it right away. But with all his power Jackie's fragile state of mind can't take the stress and soon he finds himself unable to tell reality from hallucinations and that is the highpoint of the game's narrative. Is any of this even happening? Is there really a Darkness? Yes the story is gripping and very very interesting indeed.So highly recommended? Well, no. Regardless of how great a story it tries to tell, as a game it could still be much better. At its core this is an FPS, but despite Jackie's outlandish abilities it is still too limited. All you can do is stand in the middle of a dozen enemies and shoot them or use the darkness to destroy them. That is all, no real tactics, no sneaking, nothing. After a while it just get tedious. Thankfully the game is very short, so at least you won't notice this as much. But still with a story as interesting, I wish they had paid some more attention to the game itself.I will still recommend this game. If only for the narrative and the atmosphere it creates. But this is a weak recommendation.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2012
												Darkness II is a very enjoyable game! I never played the first game and I was a bit worried that I would miss out on some key story details because of this. However this did not turn out to be the case, the games intro did a very nice job of getting caught up and throwing me right into the chaos of the story. Combat was very fluid, the action consistant and fast paced and the story easy to follow.... perhaps a bit too easy to follow as it was very predictable. Controls were addiquit, not great but not complicated (I played with mouse/keyboard). Graphics were outstanding when you consider the game was going for the cartoon look. The one major knock I have on the game is the amount of content. My first playthrough took five hours while finding nearly every relic. That's right five hours! That in mind I highly suggest the game but NOT at a full retail price, snag it for $10 or less on sale and you have yourself a great way to kill an evening!

												A well made continuation of the VIDYER GAME Darkness storyline, although some people might be turned off to the design compared to the REALISM SHOOTY STORM of the first one, it doesn't look like complete garbage like other cell-shade games. It is more linear than the console shooter, but it can focuse more on story and there is less side-quests to randomly do. Micromanaging the Gremlins was a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥so I'm glad they went to just one that showed up every now and then. The boss-fights were challanging, but fun in their own rights, and the final sequence was a great change of pace.The parts akin to "One Flew Over The Cuckoo's Nest" were well done, and really helped show how strained Jackie's relationship to the Darkness is, and the parts with Jenny were near heart-rending. So I applaud Digital Extremes for their work.

Posted: February 25, 2013
												This game was AWESOME.  The single player campaign was about 5 hours of non-stop slaughter.  The plot was solid.  You have a wonderful mix of traditional guns, dual wielding and then "darkness" powers.  There are a variety of gruesome finishing moves, lots of special abilities, and talent trees for you to get even more new ways to kill things.  The more creative you are, the more points you get, the more fun you have.  It's a lot like Bulletstorm, which if you haven't played, you should.  Another great game.  After the main campaign there is an entire other bonus campaign that you can do alone or co-op.  That, plus the random extra mini missions added another 4 hours of gameplay for me.  It also has a new game + mode so that you can keep going and max out all of your talent trees.  Awesome game that goes on sale, so keep an eye out!

Posted: September 1, 2014
												Set after a couple of years from the events of the "The Darkness", Jackie Estacado, now the leader of his own gang of mobsters, is targeted by a mysterious cult known as "The Brotherhood" who wishes to take the Darkness for themselves.Pro's: - Great story, how Jackie interacts with the Npc's and enviroments are very well done.- Fun gameplay, Use anything as a weapon to slice or inpale your foes on, or better yet, just shoot them the hell up.- Great Voice acting, many of the original voiceover's from the first game make a great return and are a treat to listen to.- Beautiful graphics, while many of the characters have a sorta "realistic cel-shaded" texture, and the backgrounds are not, it helps make characters pop out from the grim and dreary landscape.Con's:- Too Short, Though the story is great.. it can be beaten within 4-5 hours.- Confusing at times, Sometimes when you are trying to eat a heart.. your left tendril grabs a different gun instead.- Low Ammo, ammo is very scarce in the game, which is normally fine, but when you are using SMG's that require a lot of bullets... it gets tedious spam the "ammo kill" since most enemies will have protection against the Darkness attacks after the half way point.Rating: 8/10

												A dark and violent story of love and pain, quite similar at times to the one told in Max Payne, which takes you on a short but  adrenaline-filled ride through hell and back - or was it the other way around?A detailed cell-shading-like look, excellent writing and brilliant voice acting make this one a must-have for every fan of emotional and immersive storytelling.
